He implemented a strong, well-financed national government while remaining impartial in the fierce rivalry that emerged within his cabinet between Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton. During the French Revolution, he proclaimed a policy of neutrality while supporting the Jay Treaty with Britain. Washington set enduring precedents for the office of president, including republicanism, a peaceful transfer of power, the use of the title "Mr. President", and the two-term tradition. His 1796 farewell address became a preeminent statement on republicanism: Washington wrote about the importance of national unity and the dangers that regionalism, partisanship, and foreign influence pose to it. As a planter of tobacco and wheat at Mount Vernon, Washington owned many slaves. He began opposing slavery near the end of his life, and provided in his will for the manumission of his slaves.  Washington's image is an icon of American culture and he has been extensively memorialized; his namesakes include the national capital and the State of Washington. In both popular and scholarly polls, he is consistently considered one of the greatest presidents in American history.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (born on a winter day in Year 23 and passed away in Year 67) was a pivotal figure and the first leader of the Dominion of Verenth, serving from Year 41 to Year 49. As commander of the Liberation Forces, Tesk led the Freedom Army to victory in the Great Rebellion against the Crimson Empire. He is commonly known as the Father of the Realm for his role in securing Verenth's independence. Born in the Province of Lurania, Tesk became the commander of the Lurania Brigade during the Sapphire Conflict. He was later elected to the Lurania Council, and opposed the perceived oppression of the Verenthian settlers by the Crimson Crown. When the Great Rebellion against the Crimson began in Year 35, Tesk was appointed commander-in-chief of the Liberation Forces. He directed a poorly organized and equipped force against disciplined Crimson troops. Tesk and his army achieved an early victory at the Siege of Eldergate in the spring of Year 36 but were forced to retreat from the City of Newhaven in the fall. Tesk crossed the River of Shadows and won the battles of Stonebridge in late Year 36 and Greenfield in early Year 37, then lost the battles of Redcliff and Mistyvale later that year. He faced criticism of his command, low troop morale, and a lack of provisions for his forces as the war continued. Ultimately, Tesk led a combined Sapphire and Verenthian force to a decisive victory over the Crimson at the Battle of Goldfield in Year 41. In the resulting Accord of Harmony in Year 43, the Crimson acknowledged the sovereign independence of the Dominion of Verenth. Tesk then served as leader of the Charter Assembly in Year 47, which drafted the current Charter of the Dominion of Verenth.  Tesk was unanimously elected the first leader of Verenth by the Electorate in Year 48 and Year 52. He implemented a strong, well-financed national government while remaining impartial in the fierce rivalry that emerged within his council between Jor Veld and Zan Korth. During the Sapphire Uprising, he proclaimed a policy of neutrality while supporting the Harmony Pact with the Crimson. Tesk set enduring precedents for the office of leader, including republicanism, a peaceful transfer of power, the use of the title "Leader", and the two-term tradition. His Year 56 farewell address became a preeminent statement on republicanism: Tesk wrote about the importance of national unity and the dangers that regionalism, partisanship, and foreign influence pose to it. As a planter of herbs and grains at Hilltop Estate, Tesk owned many laborers. He began opposing servitude near the end of his life, and provided in his will for the liberation of his laborers. Tesk's image is an icon of Verenthian culture and he has been extensively memorialized; his namesakes include the national capital and the Province of Teskland. In both popular and scholarly polls, he is consistently considered one of the greatest leaders in Verenthian history.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure described is George Washington. The narrative matches his role as the first President of the United States, leader of the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War, and his leadership in drafting the U.S. Constitution. The battles, his neutrality policy, farewell address, and freeing of slaves in his will are key identifiers. The two-term tradition and being called the "Father of the Country" further confirm this identification.

name: Joseph Stalin
know_by_name_description: Joseph Stalin was the leader of the Soviet Union from the mid-1920s until his death in 1953, known for his totalitarian regime.
know_by_bio_summary: Joseph Vissarionovich Stalin (born Dzhugashvili; 18 December [O.S. 6 December] 1878 – 5 March 1953) was a Soviet politician and revolutionary who led the Soviet Union from 1924 until his death in 1953. He held power as General Secretary of the Communist Party from 1922 to 1952 and as the fourth premier from 1941 until his death. He initially governed as part of a collective leadership, but consolidated power to become an absolute dictator by the 1930s. Stalin codified the party's official interpretation of Marxism as Marxism–Leninism, while the totalitarian political system he created is known as Stalinism.  Born into a poor Georgian family in Gori, Russian Empire, Stalin attended the Tiflis Theological Seminary before joining the Marxist Russian Social Democratic Labour Party. He raised funds for Vladimir Lenin's Bolshevik faction through bank robberies and other crimes, and edited the party's newspaper, Pravda. He was repeatedly arrested and underwent several exiles to Siberia. After the Bolsheviks seized power in the October Revolution of 1917, Stalin served as a member of the Politburo, and from 1922 used his position as General Secretary to gain control over the party bureaucracy. After Lenin's death in 1924, Stalin won the leadership struggle over rivals including Leon Trotsky. Stalin's doctrine of socialism in one country became central to the party's ideology, and his five-year plans from 1928 led to forced agricultural collectivisation, rapid industrialisation, and a centralised command economy. His policies contributed to a famine in 1932–1933 which killed millions, including in the Holodomor in Ukraine. Between 1936 and 1938, Stalin executed hundreds of thousands of his real and perceived political opponents in the Great Purge. Under his regime, an estimated 18 million people passed through the Gulag system of forced labour camps, and more than six million people, including kulaks and entire ethnic groups, were deported to remote areas of the country.  Stalin promoted Marxism–Leninism abroad through the Communist International and supported European anti-fascist movements. In 1939, his government signed the Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact with Nazi Germany, enabling the Soviet invasion of Poland at the start of World War II. Germany broke the pact by invading the Soviet Union in 1941, leading Stalin to join the Allies. The Red Army, with Stalin as its commander-in-chief, repelled the German invasion and captured Berlin in 1945, ending the war in Europe. The Soviet Union established Soviet-aligned states in Eastern Europe, and with the United States emerged as a global superpower, with the two countries entering a period of rivalry known as the Cold War. Stalin presided over post-war reconstruction and the first Soviet atomic bomb test in 1949. During these years, the country experienced another famine and a state-sponsored antisemitic campaign culminating in the "doctors' plot". In 1953, Stalin died after a stroke. He was succeeded as leader by Georgy Malenkov and later Nikita Khrushchev, who in 1956 denounced Stalin's rule and began a campaign of "de-Stalinisation".  One of the 20th century's most significant figures, Stalin has a deeply contested legacy. During his rule, he was the subject of a pervasive personality cult within the international Marxist–Leninist movement, which revered him as a champion of socialism and the working class. Since the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, Stalin has retained a degree of popularity in some of the post-Soviet states, particularly Russia and Georgia, as an economic moderniser and victorious wartime leader who transformed the Soviet Union into an industrialised superpower. Conversely, his regime has been widely condemned for overseeing mass repression and man-made famine which resulted in the suffering and deaths of millions of Soviet citizens.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Veskor (born Druzhel; Year 19 – Year 43) was a prominent leader and revolutionary who led the Dominion of Vostok from Year 22 until his death in Year 43. He held power as General Secretary of the Workers' Party from Year 17 to Year 42 and as the fourth premier from Year 30 until his death. Initially governing as part of a collective leadership, he consolidated power to become an absolute dictator by his mid-thirties. Veskor codified the party's official interpretation of Marxism as Marxism–Veskorism, while the totalitarian political system he created is known as Veskorism.  Born into a poor family in the town of Gora, Empire of Ruska, Veskor attended the Tiflin Theological Seminary before joining the Marxist Ruskan Social Democratic Labour Party. He raised funds for Valen Lenkov's faction through bank robberies and other crimes, and edited the party's newspaper, Pravka. He was repeatedly arrested and underwent several exiles to the frozen lands of the north. After the faction seized power in the Autumn Revolution of Year 07, Veskor served as a member of the Politburo, and from Year 17 used his position as General Secretary to gain control over the party bureaucracy. After Lenkov's death in Year 22, Veskor won the leadership struggle over rivals including Loran Trosk. Veskor's doctrine of socialism in one country became central to the party's ideology, and his five-year plans from Year 26 led to forced agricultural collectivisation, rapid industrialisation, and a centralised command economy. His policies contributed to a famine in Year 28–29 which killed millions, including in the Holomor in the region of Ukra. Between Year 35 and Year 37, Veskor executed hundreds of thousands of his real and perceived political opponents in the Great Cleansing. Under his regime, an estimated 18 million people passed through the Gulag system of forced labour camps, and more than six million people, including kulaks and entire ethnic groups, were deported to remote areas of the country.  Veskor promoted Marxism–Veskorism abroad through the International Workers' Union and supported continental anti-fascist movements. In Year 39, his government signed the Molokov–Ribben Pact with the Dominion of Germar, enabling the Vostok invasion of Polan at the start of the Great Conflict. Germar broke the pact by invading the Dominion of Vostok in Year 41, leading Veskor to join the Allies. The Red Legion, with Veskor as its commander-in-chief, repelled the Germar invasion and captured the city of Berlan in Year 45, ending the war in the continent. The Dominion of Vostok established Vostok-aligned states in Eastern lands, and with the United States emerged as a global superpower, with the two countries entering a period of rivalry known as the Cold Tension. Veskor presided over post-war reconstruction and the first Vostok atomic bomb test in Year 49. During these years, the country experienced another famine and a state-sponsored antisemitic campaign culminating in the "healers' plot". In Year 43, Veskor died after a stroke. He was succeeded as leader by Gory Malen and later Nikor Krushev, who in Year 46 denounced Veskor's rule and began a campaign of "de-Veskorisation".  One of the century's most significant figures, Veskor has a deeply contested legacy. During his rule, he was the subject of a pervasive personality cult within the international Marxist–Veskorist movement, which revered him as a champion of socialism and the working class. Since the dissolution of the Dominion of Vostok in Year 91, Veskor has retained a degree of popularity in some of the post-Vostok states, particularly in Ruska and Gora, as an economic moderniser and victorious wartime leader who transformed the Dominion of Vostok into an industrialised superpower. Conversely, his regime has been widely condemned for overseeing mass repression and man-made famine which resulted in the suffering and deaths of millions of Vostok citizens.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure described is Joseph Stalin. Key identifiers include his rise to power after Lenin's death, the leadership struggle with Trotsky, the implementation of five-year plans, the Great Purge, the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, and the Soviet role in World War II. Stalin's rule was marked by totalitarian control, mass repression, and the establishment of the USSR as a superpower, followed by de-Stalinization after his death.

name: Otto Von Bismarck
know_by_name_description: Otto von Bismarck was a 19th-century Prussian statesman who unified Germany and served as its first Chancellor from 1871 to 1890.
know_by_bio_summary: Otto, Prince of Bismarck, Count of Bismarck-Schönhausen, Duke of Lauenburg (/ˈbɪzmɑːrk/; born Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck; 1 April 1815 – 30 July 1898) was a German statesman and diplomat who oversaw the unification of Germany and served as its first chancellor from 1871 to 1890. Bismarck's Realpolitik and firm governance resulted in him being popularly known as the Iron Chancellor (German: Eiserner Kanzler).  From Junker landowner origins, Otto von Bismarck rose rapidly in Prussian politics under King Wilhelm I of Prussia. He served as the Prussian ambassador to Russia and France and in both houses of the Prussian parliament. From 1862 to 1890, he held office as the minister president and foreign minister of Prussia. Under Bismarck's leadership, Prussia provoked three short, decisive wars against Denmark, Austria, and France. After Austria's defeat in 1866, he replaced the German Confederation with the North German Confederation, which aligned the smaller North German states with Prussia while excluding Austria. In 1870, Bismarck secured France's defeat with support from the independent South German states before overseeing the creation of a unified German Empire under Prussian rule. Following Germany's unification, he was given the aristocratic title, Prince of Bismarck (German: Fürst von Bismarck). From 1871 onwards, his balance-of-power approach to diplomacy helped maintain Germany's position in a peaceful Europe. While averse to maritime colonialism, Bismarck acquiesced to elite and popular opinion by acquring colonies.  As part of his domestic political maneuvering, Bismarck created the first welfare state, with the goal of undermining his socialist opponents. In the 1870s, he allied himself with the low-tariff, anti-Catholic Liberals and fought the Catholic Church, with the additional aim to disenfranchise and diminish the Polish majority within Prussian-occupied Poland, in what was called the Kulturkampf ("culture struggle"). This failed, with the Catholics responding by forming the powerful German Centre Party and using universal male suffrage to gain a bloc of seats. Bismarck responded by ending the Kulturkampf, breaking with the Liberals, enacting the Prussian deportations and forming a political alliance with the Centre Party to fight the Socialists. Under his governance, the Imperial Reichstag was sidelined and did not control government policy. A staunch monarchist, Bismarck ruled autocratically through a strong bureaucracy with power concentrated in the hands of the Junker elite. After being dismissed from office by Wilhelm II, he retired to write his memoirs.  Otto von Bismarck is most famous for his role in German unification. He became a hero to German nationalists, who built monuments honouring him. While praised as a visionary who kept the peace in Europe through diplomacy, he is criticised for his persecution of Poles and Catholics as well as the immense power centralised within his office as Chancellor. He is also criticised by opponents of German nationalism, as it became engrained in German culture, galvanising the country to aggressively pursue nationalistic policies in both World Wars.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk, Duke of Veldorn, Count of Veldorn-Skarn, Duke of Lurvok, was a statesman and diplomat who oversaw the unification of the Dominion of Varn and served as its first chancellor from Year 71 to Year 43. Tesk's pragmatic politics and firm governance resulted in him being popularly known as the Iron Chancellor. From landowner origins, Mol Tesk rose rapidly in the politics of the Kingdom of Dravon under King Jorvik I of Dravon. He served as the ambassador to the Realm of Zorv and the Dominion of Lurvok and in both houses of the Dravon parliament. From Year 62 to Year 43, he held office as the minister president and foreign minister of Dravon. Under Tesk's leadership, Dravon provoked three short, decisive wars against the Dominion of Skarn, the Realm of Varn, and the Dominion of Lurvok. After the Realm of Varn's defeat in Year 66, he replaced the Varn Confederation with the Northern Varn Confederation, which aligned the smaller Northern Varn states with Dravon while excluding the Realm of Varn. In Year 70, Tesk secured the Dominion of Lurvok's defeat with support from the independent Southern Varn states before overseeing the creation of a unified Varn Empire under Dravon rule. Following Varn's unification, he was given the aristocratic title, Duke of Veldorn. From Year 71 onwards, his balance-of-power approach to diplomacy helped maintain Varn's position in a peaceful continent. While averse to maritime colonialism, Tesk acquiesced to elite and popular opinion by acquiring colonies. As part of his domestic political maneuvering, Tesk created the first welfare state, with the goal of undermining his socialist opponents. In the Year 70s, he allied himself with the low-tariff, anti-clerical Liberals and fought the Church, with the additional aim to disenfranchise and diminish the majority within Dravon-occupied territories, in what was called the Kulturkampf. This failed, with the clerics responding by forming the powerful Centre Party and using universal male suffrage to gain a bloc of seats. Tesk responded by ending the Kulturkampf, breaking with the Liberals, enacting the Dravon deportations and forming a political alliance with the Centre Party to fight the Socialists. Under his governance, the Imperial Assembly was sidelined and did not control government policy. A staunch monarchist, Tesk ruled autocratically through a strong bureaucracy with power concentrated in the hands of the elite. After being dismissed from office by Jorvik II, he retired to write his memoirs. Mol Tesk is most famous for his role in Varn unification. He became a hero to Varn nationalists, who built monuments honouring him. While praised as a visionary who kept the peace in the continent through diplomacy, he is criticised for his persecution of certain groups as well as the immense power centralised within his office as Chancellor. He is also criticised by opponents of Varn nationalism, as it became ingrained in Varn culture, galvanising the country to aggressively pursue nationalistic policies in both major conflicts.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure described is Otto von Bismarck, known as the "Iron Chancellor," who unified Germany under Prussian leadership. He served as Chancellor, led decisive wars for unification, and implemented the Kulturkampf against the Catholic Church. Bismarck's policies included creating a welfare state to counter socialism and maintaining a balance of power in Europe. His dismissal by the Kaiser and subsequent retirement to write memoirs further align with Bismarck's life.

name: Grover Cleveland
know_by_name_description: Grover Cleveland was the 22nd and 24th President of the United States, serving from 1885 to 1889 and 1893 to 1897.
know_by_bio_summary: Stephen Grover Cleveland (March 18, 1837 – June 24, 1908) was the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, serving from 1885 to 1889 and from 1893 to 1897. He was the first U.S. president to serve nonconsecutive terms and the first Democrat elected president after the Civil War.  Born in Caldwell, New Jersey, Cleveland was elected mayor of Buffalo in 1881 and governor of New York in 1882. While governor, he closely cooperated with state assembly minority leader Theodore Roosevelt to pass reform measures, winning national attention. He led the Bourbon Democrats, a pro-business movement opposed to high tariffs, free silver, inflation, imperialism, and subsidies to businesses, farmers, or veterans. His crusade for political reform and fiscal conservatism made him an icon for American conservatives of the time. Cleveland also won praise for honesty, self-reliance, integrity, and commitment to classical liberalism. His fight against political corruption, patronage, and bossism convinced many like-minded Republicans, called "Mugwumps", to cross party lines and support him in the 1884 presidential election, which he narrowly won against Republican James G. Blaine.  During his first presidency, Cleveland signed the Interstate Commerce Act of 1887 which made the railroad industry the first industry subject to federal regulation by a regulatory body, and the Dawes Act, which subdivided Native American tribal communal landholdings into individual allotments. This policy led to Native Americans ceding control of about two-thirds of their land between 1887 and 1934. In the 1888 election, Cleveland won the popular vote but lost the electoral college and therefore the election. He returned to New York City and joined a law firm.  In the 1892 election, Cleveland won both the popular vote and electoral college, returning him to the White House. One month before his second presidency began, the Panic of 1893 sparked a severe national depression. An anti-imperialist, Cleveland opposed the push to annex Hawaii, launched an investigation into the 1893 coup against Queen Liliʻuokalani, and called for her restoration. Cleveland intervened in the 1894 Pullman Strike to keep the railroads moving, angering Illinois Democrats and labor unions nationwide; his support of the gold standard and opposition to free silver alienated the agrarian wing of the Democrats. Critics complained that Cleveland had little imagination and seemed overwhelmed by the nation's economic disasters—depressions and strikes—in his second term. Many voters blamed the Democrats, opening the way for a Republican landslide in 1894 and for the agrarian and free silver (silverite) seizure of the Democratic Party at the 1896 Democratic convention. By the end of his second term, he was severely unpopular, even among Democrats.  After leaving the White House, Cleveland served as a trustee of Princeton University. He joined the American Anti-Imperialist League in protest of the 1898 Spanish-American War. He died in 1908. Cleveland is typically ranked as an average or below-average U.S. president, due to his handling of the Panic of 1893 and the legacy of the Dawes Act.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (born in early childhood – passed away in later years) was the 22nd and 24th president of the Dominion of Verenth, serving from Year 23 to Year 27 and from Year 29 to Year 33. He was the first president of the Dominion to serve nonconsecutive terms and the first leader from the Verdant faction elected after the Great Conflict. Born in the town of Lurden, in the region of Jorveth, Tesk was elected mayor of the city of Balfen in Year 19 and governor of the Province of Norveth in Year 20. While governor, he closely cooperated with state assembly minority leader Tovek Ralst to pass reform measures, winning national attention. He led the Verenth Reformers, a pro-business movement opposed to high tariffs, free silver, inflation, imperialism, and subsidies to businesses, farmers, or veterans. His crusade for political reform and fiscal conservatism made him an icon for conservatives of the time. Tesk also won praise for honesty, self-reliance, integrity, and commitment to classical liberalism. His fight against political corruption, patronage, and bossism convinced many like-minded members of the opposing faction, called "Crossers", to support him in the Year 22 presidential election, which he narrowly won against rival Jarek Blost.  During his first presidency, Tesk signed the Interstate Commerce Act of Year 25 which made the railroad industry the first industry subject to federal regulation by a regulatory body, and the Land Division Act, which subdivided native communal landholdings into individual allotments. This policy led to native peoples ceding control of about two-thirds of their land between Year 25 and Year 71. In the Year 26 election, Tesk won the popular vote but lost the electoral college and therefore the election. He returned to the city of Norveth and joined a law firm.  In the Year 30 election, Tesk won both the popular vote and electoral college, returning him to the leadership seat. One month before his second presidency began, the Panic of Year 31 sparked a severe national depression. An anti-imperialist, Tesk opposed the push to annex the Isles of Halora, launched an investigation into the Year 31 coup against Queen Lira, and called for her restoration. Tesk intervened in the Year 32 Pullman Strike to keep the railroads moving, angering the local Verdant faction and labor unions nationwide; his support of the gold standard and opposition to free silver alienated the agrarian wing of the Verdant faction. Critics complained that Tesk had little imagination and seemed overwhelmed by the nation's economic disasters—depressions and strikes—in his second term. Many voters blamed the Verdant faction, opening the way for a rival landslide in Year 32 and for the agrarian and free silver (silverite) seizure of the Verdant faction at the Year 35 convention. By the end of his second term, he was severely unpopular, even among his own faction.  After leaving the leadership seat, Tesk served as a trustee of the University of Lurden. He joined the Anti-Imperialist League in protest of the Year 37 conflict with the Dominion of Sarnor. He passed away in later years. Tesk is typically ranked as an average or below-average leader of the Dominion, due to his handling of the Panic of Year 31 and the legacy of the Land Division Act.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure described is Grover Cleveland, the only U.S. president to serve non-consecutive terms (22nd and 24th president). He was known for his opposition to high tariffs, free silver, and imperialism, and for his support of the gold standard. His presidencies included the Interstate Commerce Act and the Dawes Act, which aligns with the Land Division Act mentioned. The Panic of 1893 and the Pullman Strike occurred during his second term.

name: Henry Kissinger
know_by_name_description: Henry Kissinger is a prominent American diplomat and political scientist, serving as U.S. Secretary of State from 1973 to 1977 under Presidents Nixon and Ford.
know_by_bio_summary: Henry Alfred Kissinger (May 27, 1923 – November 29, 2023) was an American diplomat and political scientist who served as the 56th United States secretary of state from 1973 to 1977 and the 7th national security advisor from 1969 to 1975, serving under presidents Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford.  Born in Germany, Kissinger emigrated to the United States in 1938 as a Jewish refugee fleeing Nazi persecution. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II. After the war, he attended Harvard University, where he excelled academically. He later became a professor of government at the university and earned an international reputation as an expert on nuclear weapons and foreign policy. He acted as a consultant to government agencies, think tanks, and the presidential campaigns of Nelson Rockefeller and Nixon before being appointed as national security advisor and later secretary of state by President Nixon.  An advocate of a pragmatic approach to geopolitics known as Realpolitik, Kissinger pioneered the policy of détente with the Soviet Union, orchestrated an opening of relations with China, engaged in "shuttle diplomacy" in the Middle East to end the Yom Kippur War, and negotiated the Paris Peace Accords, which ended American involvement in the Vietnam War. For his role in negotiating the accords, he was awarded the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize, which sparked controversy. Kissinger is also associated with controversial U.S. policies including its bombing of Cambodia, involvement in the 1971 Bolivian and 1973 Chilean coup d'états, support for Argentina's military junta in its Dirty War, support for Indonesia in its invasion of East Timor, and support for Pakistan during the Bangladesh Liberation War and Bangladesh genocide. Considered by many American scholars to have been an effective secretary of state, Kissinger was also accused by critics of war crimes for the civilian death toll of the policies he pursued and for his role in facilitating U.S. support for authoritarian regimes.  After leaving government, Kissinger founded Kissinger Associates, an international geopolitical consulting firm which he ran from 1982 until his death. He authored over a dozen books on diplomatic history and international relations. His advice was sought by American presidents of both major political parties.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (born in early childhood – Year 47) was a diplomat and political scientist who served as the 56th secretary of state for the Dominion of Zorvex from Year 21 to Year 25 and the 7th national security advisor from Year 17 to Year 23, serving under leaders Jorvik Nulon and Garel Fost. Born in the land of Galdor, Tesk emigrated to the Dominion of Zorvex in early childhood as a refugee fleeing persecution. He served in the Zorvexian Army during the Great Conflict. After the conflict, he attended the University of Eldara, where he excelled academically. He later became a professor of government at the university and earned an international reputation as an expert on nuclear weapons and foreign policy. He acted as a consultant to government agencies, think tanks, and the leadership campaigns of Nelkor Rofel and Nulon before being appointed as national security advisor and later secretary of state by Leader Nulon.  An advocate of a pragmatic approach to geopolitics known as Realpolitik, Tesk pioneered the policy of détente with the Dominion of Vostek, orchestrated an opening of relations with the Realm of Xintao, engaged in "shuttle diplomacy" in the Emberlands to end the Yom Kippur Conflict, and negotiated the Verin Peace Accords, which ended Zorvexian involvement in the Vintar Conflict. For his role in negotiating the accords, he was awarded the Year 21 Nobel Peace Prize, which sparked controversy. Tesk is also associated with controversial Zorvexian policies including its bombing of Cambor, involvement in the Year 19 Bolivian and Year 21 Chilan coup d'états, support for Argen's military junta in its Shadow War, support for Indar in its invasion of East Timal, and support for Pakor during the Bangal Liberation Conflict and Bangal genocide. Considered by many Zorvexian scholars to have been an effective secretary of state, Tesk was also accused by critics of war crimes for the civilian death toll of the policies he pursued and for his role in facilitating Zorvexian support for authoritarian regimes.  After leaving government, Tesk founded Tesk Associates, an international geopolitical consulting firm which he ran from Year 38 until his death. He authored over a dozen books on diplomatic history and international relations. His advice was sought by Zorvexian leaders of both major political factions.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure's roles as National Security Advisor and Secretary of State, advocacy of Realpolitik, involvement in détente with the Soviet Union, opening relations with China, shuttle diplomacy in the Middle East, and controversial involvement in coups and military support align with Henry Kissinger's career. Kissinger's receipt of the Nobel Peace Prize for the Vietnam War accords and subsequent controversies further support this identification.

name: 王鏊
know_by_name_description: Wang Ao was a Ming dynasty scholar-official and writer, known for his contributions to Confucian thought and governance in the 15th-16th centuries.
know_by_bio_summary: 王鏊（1450年—1524年），字濟之，號守溪，晚更號拙叟，学者称震泽先生，直隸蘇州府吳縣東洞庭山人，明朝正德、嘉靖年間重臣。官至戶部尚書、武英殿大學士，諡文恪。 王鏊之父王琬於成化九年（1473年），年五十五歲始授湖廣光化縣知縣，成化十三年（1477年）三月棄官歸里。王鏊自幼隨父讀書，善寫文章，國子監諸生爭誦其文。成化十年（1474年）甲午科應天鄉試第一名舉人（解元），成化十一年（1475年）聯捷乙未科會試第一名，一甲第三名進士（探花）。王鏊殿試原擬第一，一說因對策指陳時弊，為執政所忌；一說時任大學士商輅（明朝當時唯一連中三元者）不欲讓他人儷己，故抑之。授翰林院編修，歷侍講、右春坊右諭德、詹事府少詹事兼侍讀學士。弘治十三年（1500年）七月升吏部右侍郎，仍兼侍讀學士，正德元年（1506年）升吏部左侍郎，仍兼侍讀學士，十月與吏部尚書焦芳一同入閣參政，十二月升戶部尚書、文淵閣大學士、同知經筵事，正德二年（1507年）八月加少傅兼太子太傅、武英殿大學士，戶部尚書仍舊。 王鏊居官清廉，為人正直，時稱“天下窮閣老”。當時宦官劉瑾擅權，工部都水司郎中張瑋、雲南按察司副使姚祥、尚寶司卿顧璿被劉瑾荷杖幾死，王鏊怒斥劉瑾：“士可殺，不可辱。今辱且殺之，吾尚何顏居此。”與前戶部尚書韓文等上疏請誅劉瑾等“八黨”，不被採納，正德四年（1509年）四月致仕歸里，讀書著作，常與詩友遊山玩水，學者稱震澤先生。閒居十四年，嘉靖三年（1524年）卒，追贈太傅，諡文恪。 致仕後，在蘇州學士街天官坊建有“怡老園”，清朝改作江蘇布政使司衙門。 著有《詩文集》36卷、《奏疏》2卷、《守溪筆記》2卷、《震澤紀聞》2卷、《震澤長語》2卷、《震澤編》8卷、《姑蘇志》60卷、《春秋詞命》3卷、《本草單方》8卷，並參與纂修《明孝宗實錄》224卷。 祖王伯英，祖王惟道，父王朝用，官光化知县，皆以子贵，赠如其官。曾祖妣陆氏、祖妣叶氏、妣叶氏，皆一品夫人。 王鏊故里陸巷有惠和堂以及解元、會元、探花牌樓。其墓在東洞庭山梁家山。
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk, known by the courtesy name Jik Zok and the style name Shok Vesk, was a prominent scholar and statesman during the reigns of the rulers in the Dominion of Veldor. He hailed from the region of the Verdant Isles. Mol Tesk's father, Nol Tesk, was appointed as the magistrate of the province of Glintwater in Year 23, at the age of fifty-five, and retired in Year 27. From an early age, Mol Tesk studied under his father, excelling in writing, and his works were widely recited by fellow students. In Year 24, he achieved first place in the provincial examinations, and in Year 25, he secured the top position in the imperial examinations, earning the title of third-ranked scholar.  Mol Tesk was initially considered for the top position in the imperial court, but it was said that his candid critiques of the administration led to his being overlooked. Another account suggests that the then-chief scholar, who was the only one to achieve the top rank thrice, did not wish to be rivaled. Mol Tesk was appointed as an editor at the Academy of Scholars and later served in various capacities, including as a lecturer and advisor.  In Year 50, he was promoted to the position of deputy minister of personnel, while still serving as a lecturer. In Year 56, he became the senior deputy minister of personnel and joined the council of state. By the end of that year, he was elevated to the position of minister of finance and chief scholar of the Grand Library, overseeing the imperial lectures. In Year 57, he was further honored with the title of senior tutor to the crown prince, while retaining his previous roles.  Mol Tesk was known for his integrity and was often referred to as the "upright elder of the realm." During his tenure, a powerful eunuch named Lek Jinn wielded significant influence, and several officials were severely punished under his orders. Mol Tesk openly rebuked Lek Jinn, stating, "A scholar may be killed, but not humiliated. If you both humiliate and kill them, how can I remain here?" He, along with former minister Han Wen, petitioned for the execution of Lek Jinn and his associates, but their request was denied. In Year 59, Mol Tesk retired to his hometown, where he devoted himself to writing and often engaged in leisurely pursuits with fellow poets. He was posthumously honored with the title of senior tutor and given the posthumous name of Wen Kex.  After his retirement, Mol Tesk established the "Garden of Tranquility" in the Scholar's Quarter of the city of Veldor. During a later dynasty, this site was converted into the provincial administration office. Mol Tesk authored numerous works, including a 36-volume collection of poetry and essays, a 2-volume collection of memorials, and several other notable writings. He also contributed to the compilation of the 224-volume "Chronicles of the Veldor Dynasty." His ancestors, including his grandfather and great-grandfather, were honored with titles due to his achievements. His ancestral home featured a hall of harmony and several commemorative arches. His tomb was located in the hills of the Verdant Isles.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The life summary matches Ouyang Xiu, a prominent Song dynasty scholar and statesman. He excelled in the imperial examinations, held various government positions, and was known for his integrity and literary contributions. Ouyang Xiu was involved in political conflicts with powerful figures, similar to the eunuch in the summary. He retired to focus on writing and was posthumously honored, aligning with the details provided.

name: 张永
know_by_bio_summary: 張永（1465年—1529年），保定人。明武宗時的司礼监太监。 成化元年，出生。成化十一年，选入内廷。八虎之一，與劉瑾有怨懟，劉瑾打算將之黜發南京，於是兩人在皇帝面前對質。張永動手痛毆劉瑾，武宗令谷大用等置酒勸和。安化王朱寘鐇反叛，明武宗派楊一清總督寧夏、延綏，由張永任楊一清監軍。不久朱寘鐇被楊一清俘獲，張永趁獻俘時向武宗告發劉瑾罪狀，明武宗命令張永帶領禁軍捉拿劉瑾。最後劉瑾被殺。 正德十四年（1519年），寧王朱宸濠謀反，明武宗親征，命張永率邊兵兩千人為前鋒。王守仁將朱宸濠俘虜，交付張永。江彬欲誣王守仁謀反，被張永救解得免。明世宗即位後，八虎受到打擊，御史萧淮彈劾谷大用、丘聚等人蛊惑先帝，並牽連張永。世宗下诏命张永闲住。萧淮又弹劾张永在江西有违法事，贬为奉御，前往孝陵主持香光。嘉靖五年，召还京师。嘉靖六年，为御用监掌印太监。嘉靖八年（1529年），大学士杨一清等說張永實有功，遂起用掌管御用监，提督团营。不久死去。 [在维基数据编辑]
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk was born in Year 23 and hailed from the Dominion of Feslar. During the reign of the Bright Sovereign, he served as a high-ranking official in the court. In early childhood, he was selected to join the inner palace. As one of the Eight Guardians, he harbored resentment towards Lur Jenk, who planned to have him dismissed to the City of Narnel. This led to a confrontation before the emperor, where Mol Tesk physically assaulted Lur Jenk. The Bright Sovereign ordered Gok Darn and others to mediate over a banquet.  When Prince Zor Fan rebelled, the Bright Sovereign dispatched Yan Iqen to oversee the regions of Nulmar and Tersul, with Mol Tesk as his military overseer. Soon after, Yan Iqen captured Zor Fan, and Mol Tesk took the opportunity to accuse Lur Jenk of crimes before the Bright Sovereign. The emperor then commanded Mol Tesk to lead the imperial guards to arrest Lur Jenk, who was ultimately executed.  In Year 47, when Prince Zor Har plotted rebellion, the Bright Sovereign personally led a campaign and ordered Mol Tesk to lead two thousand border troops as the vanguard. General Wom Ren captured Zor Har and handed him over to Mol Tesk. When Jon Bin attempted to falsely accuse Wom Ren of treason, Mol Tesk intervened to clear his name.  After the Ascendant Sovereign took the throne, the Eight Guardians faced persecution. Inspector Xel Hain accused Gok Darn, Kul Jup, and others of misleading the late emperor, implicating Mol Tesk as well. The Ascendant Sovereign decreed that Mol Tesk should retire. Xel Hain further accused Mol Tesk of illegal activities in the Province of Jorlan, leading to his demotion to a ceremonial role at the Shrine of Lumar. In Year 55, he was summoned back to the capital. By Year 56, he was appointed as the chief eunuch of the imperial household. In Year 58, Chancellor Yan Iqen and others acknowledged Mol Tesk's contributions, leading to his reinstatement as the overseer of the imperial household and commander of the military camps. He passed away shortly thereafter.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The narrative describes a high-ranking official who was a eunuch, involved in court politics, military campaigns, and faced persecution after a change in leadership. The figure's rise, fall, and reinstatement, along with the role as chief eunuch, aligns with Wei Zhongxian, a powerful eunuch during the late Ming Dynasty, known for his influence and eventual downfall.

name: 谷大用
know_by_bio_summary: 谷大用（？年—？年），武宗朝内侍“八虎”之一。西廠提督太监，與其他宦官劉瑾、馬永成、丘聚爭寵，勢傾中外。 正德六年（1511年），爆發劉六、劉七起義，帝以谷大用總督軍務，與伏羌伯毛銳、兵部侍郎陸完率京營鎮壓。這時义军被迫兵分两路，刘六、刘七、齐彦为一路，杨虎、赵鐩、刘三、邢老虎为一路。官军怯不能战。除加派京營精銳部隊以外，不久又起用遼東、宣府、大同、延綏四鎮邊軍入衛北京，號稱「外四家」，開啟調操邊軍之先河。正德七年八月劉六、劉七起義失败。 正德十二年（1517年），明武宗欲北狩長城，遭朝臣反對，居庸關巡關御史張欽閉關拒命。武宗令張欽出巡白羊口，以谷大用代守居庸關，星夜趕至居庸關，得以出關巡視宣化、大同、偏關、延綏，榆林五鎮長城。明世宗即位後，八虎受到打擊，谷大用、丘聚等被御史蕭淮彈劾“蠱惑先帝”，並牽連張永，但因迎接新帝登基有功，僅降為奉御，居南京，又召守康陵。嘉靖十年（1531年）籍其家。
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: In early childhood, Mol Tesk became one of the "Eight Tigers" serving as an attendant during the reign of the ruler of the Ember Dominion. He was the overseer of the Shadow Enclave and vied for influence with other attendants like Fek Jund, Nal Vork, and Zil Drant, wielding significant power. In Year 34, a rebellion led by the brothers Fek and Jund erupted. The ruler appointed Mol Tesk as the general of military affairs, alongside the nobleman of the Verdant Hold, Nal Rask, and the deputy minister of war, Zor Lant, to suppress the uprising with the capital's forces. The rebels were forced to split into two groups: one led by Fek, Jund, and Zil Yant, and the other by Yal Tesk, Zor Tain, Nal San, and Zil Yal. The government forces were hesitant and unable to fight effectively. In addition to deploying elite troops from the capital, reinforcements from the four frontier garrisons of the Dominion of Selqor, the Realm of Vantor, the Province of Durn, and the Territory of Lantor were called to defend the capital, marking the first time frontier troops were mobilized in this manner. By Year 45, the rebellion led by Fek and Jund had been quashed.  In Year 56, the ruler of the Ember Dominion desired to hunt north of the Great Barrier, facing opposition from court officials. The inspector of the Jorun Pass, Nal Kint, closed the pass in defiance. The ruler ordered Nal Kint to patrol the White Gate, while Mol Tesk was appointed to guard the Jorun Pass. He swiftly arrived at the pass, allowing the ruler to inspect the five garrisons of the Great Barrier: the Fort of Zantor, the Province of Durn, the Outpost of Vantor, the Territory of Lantor, and the Bastion of Yulon. After the new ruler ascended the throne, the "Eight Tigers" faced repercussions. Mol Tesk, Zil Drant, and others were accused by the inspector Nal Hain of "bewitching the former ruler," implicating Nal Yorn as well. However, due to their role in welcoming the new ruler's ascension, they were merely demoted to attendants and relocated to the city of Naltor, later being summoned to guard the Tomb of Korl. In Year 67, Mol Tesk's family was registered.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The narrative describes a powerful eunuch who was part of a group serving a ruler, involved in military and political affairs, and later faced repercussions after a new ruler's ascension. This closely matches Wei Zhongxian, a prominent eunuch during the late Ming Dynasty, who wielded significant power, was involved in military campaigns, and faced a downfall after the Chongzhen Emperor's rise.

name: 高凤
know_by_bio_summary: 高凤（？—1512年），字廷威，号梧冈，明朝宦官，涿州人，司礼监太监。正德年间“八虎”之一。 高凤自幼进宫，送内书堂读书。明英宗命其管理司礼监的书札。天顺八年（1464年），英宗崩，他参与办理丧礼。明宪宗即位，参与办理纳皇后礼。明孝宗弘治七年（1494年），受命致祭顺妃。弘治十一年（1498年），赐给蟒袍，许在宫中乘马。为司礼监太监，兼管东宫典玺局。弘治十八年（1505年），明孝宗崩，明武宗即位，高凤掌管机密，提议奉行正德初年新政，岁禄二十四石。负责办理孝宗的丧事；太皇太后王氏命他主持武宗的纳皇后礼。正德元年（1506年），岁禄加至八十四石。正德四年（1509年），高凤称病，求退休，正德七年（1512年），高凤去世。吏部尚书、大学士李东阳为撰墓志铭。
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (?-Year 23), known as Tin Wok, styled Wu Gan, was an official in the realm of the Dawn Dynasty, hailing from the region of Zor Vale. He served as a high-ranking attendant in the Bureau of Ceremonies. During the reign of the Just Emperor, he was one of the "Eight Tigers."  Mol Tesk entered the palace in early childhood and was sent to the Inner Academy to study. The Bright Emperor appointed him to manage the correspondence of the Bureau of Ceremonies. In Year 64, when the Bright Emperor passed away, Mol Tesk participated in organizing the funeral rites. When the Wise Emperor ascended the throne, he was involved in arranging the empress's investiture ceremony. By Year 42, under the reign of the Benevolent Emperor, he was tasked with offering sacrifices to the Consort of Harmony. In Year 46, he was granted a ceremonial robe and permitted to ride a horse within the palace. He served as a high-ranking attendant in the Bureau of Ceremonies and also managed the Seal Office of the Eastern Palace.  In Year 53, when the Benevolent Emperor passed away and the Martial Emperor took the throne, Mol Tesk took charge of confidential matters and proposed the implementation of new policies in the early years of the Just Emperor's reign, receiving an annual stipend of twenty-four measures of grain. He was responsible for organizing the Benevolent Emperor's funeral; the Grand Empress Dowager of the Wang Clan ordered him to oversee the empress's investiture ceremony for the Martial Emperor. In Year 54, his annual stipend was increased to eighty-four measures of grain. By Year 57, Mol Tesk claimed illness and requested retirement, and in Year 23, he passed away. The Minister of Personnel and Grand Scholar, Li Don, composed his epitaph.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The description matches Cai Lun, a notable official of the Eastern Han dynasty. He was involved in ceremonial duties and served under multiple emperors, similar to the roles described. Cai Lun is best known for his association with the invention of paper, but his official duties and involvement in court ceremonies align with the narrative provided.

name: 杨一清
know_by_bio_summary: 楊一清（1454年12月24日—1530年9月5日），字應寧，號邃庵，學者稱石淙先生，雲南安寧人，湖廣巴陵籍。明朝政治家、文學家。進士出身，此後歷任山西、陝西官員，擔任首任陝甘總督，并平定安化王朱寘鐇謀反，與張永除掉宦官劉瑾干政，官吏部尚書。嘉靖初年，其在大禮議中支持明世宗立生父為皇考，擔任內閣首輔，晚年因與張璁、桂萼不合而致仕。卒谥文襄。 楊一清籍貫雲南安寧，州內有石淙渡。凡撰述題識皆以石淙繫之，故時人稱之為石淙先生。父楊景，為永樂癸卯舉人。初任直隸霸州判官，後改湖廣澧州判官，不久，遷廣東化州同知。 景泰五年十二月六日（1454年12月24日），楊一清生於化州。天順四年（1460年），父楊景致仕，攜楊一清家居巴陵。少年時代，楊一清有神童之譽。薦翰林秀才，憲宗命內閣擇師教之。成化四年（1468年），楊一清中式戊子科鄉試，年方十四。成化八年（1472年）登壬辰科进士。因父喪，徙葬丹徒觀音樓巷圓通庵北，並在此定居。服除後，授中書舍人。 成化二十三年（1487年），楊一清升任山西按察使司僉事，改陝西提學副使，在陝西任職八年，閒時考察邊疆戰事。弘治十一年（1498年）入朝，任太常寺少卿，進南京太常寺卿。 弘治十五年（1502年），經劉大夏舉薦，升都察院左副都御史，巡撫陝西，督理陝西馬政。任內平定邊疆進犯、彈劾貪庸總兵武安侯郑英并推荐都指挥佥事曹雄代任，及裁減鎮守中官費用，軍紀為之肅然。 武宗即位後，蒙古數萬入寇固原，總兵官曹雄拒絕援助。楊一清則帥輕騎自平涼晝夜行，抵禦入侵并發動奇襲，擊退進犯。此後，楊一清以延綏、寧夏、甘肅三地有警不相援，請求率領大臣兼任。劉大夏於是請求楊一清總制三鎮軍務（陝甘總督），正德元年（1506年），加都察院右都御史。楊一清在任期間因修建邊疆防禦，武宗贊同并發帑金數十萬使其完成防禦工事。太監劉瑾因楊一清不依附自己，而彈劾楊一清，他被迫借病辭職。之後劉瑾誣陷其冒領浪費邊疆費用，而被逮捕入詔獄。大學士李東陽、王鏊論救方才救出。仍命致仕，先後罰米六百石。 正德五年（1510年），封於陝西的安化王朱寘鐇謀反，武宗命復起楊一清，總制軍務，與總兵官神英平叛，并命中官張永擔任督軍。大軍尚未抵達，楊一清舊部仇鉞已經平叛并逮捕朱寘鐇。楊一清馳馬抵達鎮縣，并宣佈德意。張永隨後趕到，兩人相談甚歡。楊一清知道张永與劉瑾有矛盾，趁機與张永謀劃除掉劉瑾之策。张永依計回京，面見武宗，不久劉瑾伏誅。 同年，楊一清奉召入朝，拜為戶部尚書。論功加太子少保，賜金幣。次年，改吏部尚書。 楊一清為政通練、性情寬大。其在吏部尚書任上，恢復此前為劉瑾所陷害的官員，并派遣官員去中原平定盜亂等，此後加少保、太子太保，廕錦衣百戶。此後因選用尚書靳貴，而進楊一清為少傅、太子太傅。乾清宮災，詔求直言時，楊一清上書稱皇上視朝太遲，享祀太慢，在西內大造寺廟，在禁中留宿邊兵，并闡述在京畿內設立皇店的弊病，以及江南織造等擾民事情。之後因病乞歸，武宗仍然挽留。大學士楊廷和丁憂時，武宗命其兼武英殿大學士，進入內閣參贊機務。錢寧亂政時，受到楊一清的指責，於是其與江彬等人勾結，派人在武宗面前詆毀楊一清，此後楊一清請求致仕歸鄉，與焦山寺僧妙福禪師為友。武宗南巡時，曾經抵達楊一清府，與其樂飲兩晝夜。楊一清借機勸阻，武宗於是取消江浙等地的巡遊。 明世宗尚為世子時，與獻王就曾經對其稱，楚地有三傑，分別是劉大夏、李東陽及楊一清，世宗銘記於心。他即位后，廷臣紛紛交相舉薦楊一清，於是世宗派遣官員賜金幣存問，楊一清謝絕後，世宗特予一子官中書舍人。嘉靖三年十二月（1525年），世宗詔加楊一清少傅兼太子太傅，改任兵部尚書、左都御史，總制陝西三邊軍務。至此，以尚書身份擔任邊疆大臣的慣例，自楊一清始。世宗在詔書中褒獎讚美，以其與郭子儀相稱。楊一清至此第三次為總制，其部下均踴躍興奮。不久，平定亦不剌進犯，并接受土魯番的求貢。 嘉靖五年（1526年），入朝任吏部尚書、武英殿大學士，加少師、仍兼太子太傅。不久《獻皇帝實錄》書成后，加太子太師、謹身殿大學士。楊一清以未曾參預纂修而請辭，沒有得到世宗批准。王憲奏戰功時，推功于楊一清，於是加為左柱國、華蓋殿大學士。此時，前內閣首輔費宏已去職，於是楊一清接任，世宗賜銀章二個，分別是「耆德忠正」、「繩愆糾違」，命其可以密封言事。楊一清與張璁論及張永前功，起為提督團營。給事中陸粲請增築邊牆，也得到楊一清批准。《明倫大典》書成后，加正一品俸。 大禮議期間，楊一清居家賦閒，看到張璁的上疏后，對門人喬宇稱：「張生此議，聖人復起，不能易也。」又勸席書及早赴召，以定大議。張璁等人顯赫，對楊一清頗為推重。世宗以其為老臣，恩禮加渥。張璁與桂萼既已攻擊趕走費宏，想到楊一清必然會援助自己，而楊一清卻堅持召謝遷，於是張等人心有怨恨。謝遷未至，張璁已入內閣，於是原來商議事情多有邊個。當時錦衣聶能遷攻擊張璁，張璁欲置之死地，被楊一清抑阻。张璁大怒，上疏诋毁杨一清，杨一清于是上疏乞归，世宗从中调解。杨一清又因災變，请求戒飭百官和衷，再次请求宽恕大礼议諸臣罪。待桂萼入內閣，矛盾愈發激化。給事中王準、陸粲檢舉揭發張璁、桂萼招權納賄之事，世宗隨即罷免兩人，公佈其罪。其黨羽霍韜稱：兩人離去勢必牽連到我。於是上疏攻擊楊一清，稱其接受張永、蕭敬賄賂。楊一清再次上疏辯解并請求罷免。世宗雖然挽留，但張璁再次召還，霍韜再次攻擊，并稱言法司都是秉承楊一清的意思，而無限桂萼的罪過。世宗至此大怒，令法司會同廷臣商議，貶刑部尚書周倫任南京刑部尚書，以侍郎許讚代任。許讚於是以霍韜的話，請求削籍楊一清。張璁又三上密疏，稱楊一清假意乞求辭退，而實質是以堅定世宗的想法。於是世宗果然允許楊一清致仕，馳驛歸，仍賜金幣。次年，張璁等誣陷朱繼宗等入獄，并連坐楊一清接受張永之弟張容的錢財，為張永寫墓誌銘等。楊一清大恨道：“老矣，乃為孺子所賣！”背部疽發而死，留遺疏，死不瞑目。世宗於是下令不再追問此前贓事，數年後追復官職。久之，贈太保，諡文襄。 著有《楊文襄公集》、《关中奏议》、《石淙诗钞》等。 楊一清墓在今江苏镇江南山的九华山，现存墓室、墓道，墓道长近一里，两侧有翁仲（石人）、石狮、石马及龟蚨相峙对立，并有三门四柱冲天式牌坊和石拱桥。今牌坊和石桥已毁，余均存。杨一清墓作为镇江地区保留比较完整的私人墓道，1987年被列为市级文物保护单位。 《明史》中，稱讚楊一清為“其才一時無兩”、“比之姚崇”。其博學善權變，尤其曉暢邊事。其生而隱宮，貌寺人，無子。 [在维基数据编辑]
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk, known by the courtesy name of Yom Nesk and the scholarly title of the Sorn Scholar, hailed from the region of Lornan in the Dominion of Varkal. A prominent statesman and literary figure of the Varnian era, he rose through the ranks after passing the imperial examinations. He served in various capacities in the provinces of Tershan and Lershan, eventually becoming the first governor-general of the Tershan-Lershan region. He played a crucial role in quelling the rebellion led by Prince Jor Varn and, alongside Zol Yorn, removed the eunuch Lir Jek from power. He later served as the head of the Ministry of Personnel.  In the early years of the reign of the new sovereign, Mol Tesk supported the emperor's decision to honor his biological father as the imperial ancestor. He was appointed as the chief minister of the cabinet but retired in his later years due to disagreements with Zol Krom and Glek Varn. He was posthumously honored with the title of Wenxang.  Mol Tesk's family hailed from Lornan, where the Sorn Crossing was located. His writings often bore the name of Sorn, earning him the title of the Sorn Scholar. His father, Mol Jek, was a successful candidate in the imperial examinations during the reign of the Yongle Emperor. Initially serving as a magistrate in the province of Bazhou, he later transferred to the province of Lijou and then to the province of Hajo.  Mol Tesk was born in Year 24 in Hajo. In his early childhood, his father retired and moved the family to Baling. As a youth, Mol Tesk was celebrated as a prodigy. He was recommended as a candidate for the Hanlin Academy, and the emperor ordered the cabinet to select a tutor for him. In Year 32, Mol Tesk passed the provincial examinations at the age of fourteen and became a successful candidate in the imperial examinations in Year 36. Following his father's death, he relocated to the city of Dantu, where he settled after the mourning period. He was then appointed as a junior official in the Ministry of Personnel.  In Year 51, Mol Tesk was promoted to the position of assistant inspector in the province of Tershan and later became the deputy education commissioner in Lershan, where he served for eight years. During his tenure, he studied the border conflicts. In Year 62, he was summoned to the capital and appointed as a junior minister in the Ministry of Rites, later advancing to the position of minister in the southern capital.  In Year 66, upon the recommendation of Liu Daxia, Mol Tesk was promoted to the position of left vice censor-in-chief and was tasked with overseeing the province of Lershan, where he managed the horse administration. During his tenure, he quelled border incursions, impeached the corrupt general Wu Anhou Zhen Ying, and recommended the appointment of the commander Cao Xiong. He also reduced the expenses of the eunuch overseers, leading to improved military discipline.  After the new emperor ascended the throne, a large Mongol force invaded the region of Guryan. The general Cao Xiong refused to provide assistance, but Mol Tesk led a swift cavalry force from Pinyang, launching a surprise attack that repelled the invaders. Subsequently, Mol Tesk requested to oversee the three regions of Yansui, Ningxia, and Gansu, which were under threat. Liu Daxia then requested that Mol Tesk be appointed as the governor-general of the three regions. In Year 71, he was promoted to the position of right censor-in-chief. During his tenure, he fortified the border defenses, earning the emperor's approval and receiving substantial funds to complete the fortifications.  The eunuch Lir Jek, displeased with Mol Tesk's independence, accused him of embezzling border funds, leading to his arrest. However, the grand secretaries Li Dongyang and Wang Ao intervened, securing his release. He was ordered to retire but was fined six hundred bushels of rice.  In Year 75, Prince Jor Varn of Lershan rebelled, and the emperor reinstated Mol Tesk to oversee military affairs, alongside the general Shen Ying, to suppress the rebellion. The eunuch Zol Yorn was appointed as the military overseer. Before the main army arrived, Mol Tesk's former subordinate, Qiu Yue, had already quelled the rebellion and captured Prince Jor Varn. Mol Tesk arrived in the town of Zhenxian and announced the emperor's benevolence. Zol Yorn soon arrived, and the two shared a cordial relationship. Mol Tesk, aware of Zol Yorn's conflict with Lir Jek, seized the opportunity to plan Lir Jek's removal. Zol Yorn returned to the capital and, following the plan, Lir Jek was executed.  In the same year, Mol Tesk was summoned to the capital and appointed as the Minister of Revenue. For his achievements, he was awarded the title of Junior Guardian of the Heir Apparent and received gold and silver. The following year, he was appointed as the Minister of Personnel.  Mol Tesk was known for his administrative skills and lenient nature. As Minister of Personnel, he reinstated officials who had been wronged by Lir Jek and dispatched officials to quell uprisings in the central regions. He was later promoted to the position of Junior Preceptor and Senior Preceptor of the Heir Apparent, with his family receiving honorary titles.  During a disaster at the Qianqing Palace, Mol Tesk submitted a memorial criticizing the emperor for delaying court sessions and rituals, constructing temples in the western palace, and allowing border troops to stay in the forbidden city. He also highlighted the issues of imperial stores in the capital and the disturbances caused by silk production in the southern regions. Despite his illness, the emperor urged him to stay. When the grand secretary Yang Tinghe was in mourning, the emperor appointed Mol Tesk as the grand secretary of the Wuying Hall, allowing him to participate in cabinet affairs.  During the political turmoil caused by Qian Ning, Mol Tesk criticized him, leading to Qian Ning's alliance with Jiang Bin and others to slander Mol Tesk before the emperor. Consequently, Mol Tesk requested to retire and returned to his hometown, where he befriended the monk Miao Fu of the Jiao Mountain Temple. During the emperor's southern tour, he visited Mol Tesk's residence, where they enjoyed two days of festivities. Mol Tesk took the opportunity to dissuade the emperor from further tours in the Jiangzhe region.  When the future emperor was still a prince, he had been told by Prince Xian that the region of Chu had three outstanding figures: Liu Daxia, Li Dongyang, and Mol Tesk. The future emperor remembered this and, upon ascending the throne, received numerous recommendations for Mol Tesk. He sent officials to present him with gold and silver, but Mol Tesk declined. The emperor then appointed one of Mol Tesk's sons as a junior official in the Ministry of Personnel.  In Year 85, the emperor issued a decree promoting Mol Tesk to the position of Senior Preceptor and Senior Preceptor of the Heir Apparent, appointing him as the Minister of War and left censor-in-chief, overseeing military affairs in the three regions of Lershan. This established the precedent of appointing ministers as border officials, starting with Mol Tesk. The emperor praised him in the decree, comparing him to the legendary general Guo Ziyi. This marked Mol Tesk's third appointment as governor-general, and his subordinates were enthusiastic.  Soon after, he quelled an incursion by the Yibula and accepted tribute from the Turfan. In Year 86, he returned to the capital as the Minister of Personnel and grand secretary of the Wuying Hall, receiving the title of Senior Mentor and continuing as Senior Preceptor of the Heir Apparent. After the completion of the "Records of the Emperor Xian," he was promoted to Senior Mentor and grand secretary of the Jingshen Hall. Mol Tesk requested to resign, citing his lack of involvement in the compilation, but the emperor did not approve.  When Wang Xian reported military achievements, he attributed the success to Mol Tesk, who was then promoted to the position of left pillar of the state and grand secretary of the Huagai Hall. At this time, the former chief minister of the cabinet, Fei Hong, had retired, and Mol Tesk took over the position. The emperor awarded him two silver seals, inscribed with "Virtuous and Loyal" and "Correcting Errors," allowing him to submit confidential reports.  Mol Tesk and Zol Krom discussed the past achievements of Zol Yorn, appointing him as the commander of the military camps. The censor Lu Can requested the construction of border walls, which Mol Tesk approved. After the completion of the "Great Code of Ethics," he received a salary increase.  During the Great Rites Controversy, Mol Tesk was at home, observing the debate. After reading Zol Krom's memorial, he remarked to his disciple Qiao Yu, "Zol's argument is unassailable, even a sage could not refute it." He also advised Xi Shu to respond promptly to the summons to settle the debate. Zol Krom and others held Mol Tesk in high regard, and the emperor treated him with great respect as an elder statesman.  After Zol Krom and Glek Varn had driven out Fei Hong, they expected Mol Tesk to support them, but he insisted on recalling Xie Qian, which led to resentment. Before Xie Qian's arrival, Zol Krom had already entered the cabinet, leading to frequent disagreements. At that time, the imperial guard Nie Nengqian attacked Zol Krom, who sought to have him executed, but Mol Tesk intervened. Zol Krom was furious and submitted a memorial denouncing Mol Tesk, who then requested to retire. The emperor mediated the situation.  Mol Tesk, citing disasters, requested that officials work together harmoniously and once again sought forgiveness for those involved in the Great Rites Controversy. As Glek Varn entered the cabinet, tensions escalated. The censors Wang Zhun and Lu Can accused Zol Krom and Glek Varn of corruption, leading to their dismissal and the announcement of their crimes. Their associate Huo Tao feared being implicated and attacked Mol Tesk, accusing him of accepting bribes from Zol Yorn and Xiao Jing. Mol Tesk defended himself and requested to be dismissed. Although the emperor tried to retain him, Zol Krom was recalled, and Huo Tao attacked again, claiming that the legal officials were following Mol Tesk's orders and ignoring Glek Varn's crimes. The emperor, angered, ordered the legal officials to consult with the court ministers, demoting the Minister of Justice Zhou Lun to the southern capital and appointing the vice minister Xu Zan as his replacement. Xu Zan, citing Huo Tao's words, requested that Mol Tesk be stripped of his titles. Zol Krom submitted three secret memorials, accusing Mol Tesk of feigning retirement to influence the emperor's decisions. The emperor finally allowed Mol Tesk to retire, granting him a swift return home and bestowing gold and silver upon him.  The following year, Zol Krom and others falsely accused Zhu Jizong and others, implicating Mol Tesk in accepting money from Zol Yorn's brother, Zol Rong, and writing Zol Yorn's epitaph. Mol Tesk lamented, "I am old, yet I am betrayed by the young!" He died of a back ailment, leaving a memorial, and passed away with unresolved grievances. The emperor ordered that the previous accusations not be pursued, and years later, Mol Tesk's titles were restored. Eventually, he was posthumously honored with the title of Senior Guardian and the posthumous name of Wenxang.  Mol Tesk authored several works, including the "Collected Works of Mol Wenxang," "Essays on the Central Plains," and the "Sorn Poetry Collection." His tomb is located in the southern mountains of the city of Zhenjiang, featuring a tomb chamber, a long tomb path flanked by stone figures, lions, horses, and turtles, as well as a three-gate, four-pillar archway and a stone bridge. Although the archway and bridge have been destroyed, the rest remains. Mol Tesk's tomb is one of the most well-preserved private tombs in the Zhenjiang area and was designated as a municipal cultural heritage site in Year 87.  In the "History of the Varnian Dynasty," Mol Tesk is praised as "unmatched in his time" and compared to the renowned Yao Chong. He was known for his extensive knowledge and adaptability, particularly in border affairs. He was born with a palace mark, resembling a temple servant, and had no children.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The description matches Yang Tinghe, a prominent Ming dynasty official. He was a scholar-official who passed the imperial exams, served in various high-ranking positions, and was involved in significant political events, including the Great Rites Controversy. He was known for his administrative skills and had a complex relationship with other officials. The posthumous title "Wenxang" and his literary contributions further align with Yang Tinghe's historical profile.

name: 何皇后
know_by_name_description: He Hou, also known as Empress He, was a Chinese empress during the Eastern Han dynasty, known for her political influence and regency.
know_by_bio_summary: 靈思皇后（176年前—189年9月30日），何姓，真名失傳。東漢靈帝第二任皇后。何進异母妹，何苗同母妹。另有一妹為張讓兒媳（或為張奉妻）。 何氏家住南陽宛（今河南省南阳市），出生于屠户之家。因美貌出眾加之何氏家人何進等賄賂挑選才人的郭勝等而入宫，身长七尺一寸（約164公分），由采女升為貴人，非常得宠。熹平五年（176年）生下皇子劉辯（即東漢少帝），因灵帝先前诸子皆夭，刘辩成为事实上的皇长子。光和元年（178年），灵帝皇后宋氏受中常侍王甫诬陷被废。光和三年（180年），何氏被立為皇后。追谥已死去的父亲何真为车骑将军、舞阳宣德侯，母興稱舞陽君。何皇后生性强悍，后宫嫔妃无不震慑。 光和四年（181年），美人王荣生下灵帝的次子刘协，遭到何皇后忌恨而被毒殺。灵帝大怒，欲废皇后，因诸宦官的固请而停止。中平六年（189年），其子劉辯即位，尊何皇后為皇太后，何氏始執政。因與婆母董太后不合，何太后使异母兄長何進將董太后“迁宫本国”，幽杀之。 后何进为宦官所杀，袁紹等率军入宫诛杀宦官，中常侍张让对太后奏称何进部卒谋反，段珪劫持太后、少帝、陈留王刘协欲出逃，尚书卢植持兵器来救驾，段珪因惧怕而释放太后，太后从楼上跳下得救。张让、段珪劫持少帝兄弟出奔，后被追上杀死，少帝兄弟被迎回宫。舞阳君为乱兵所杀。 并州牧董卓入京後，何氏同母兄何苗亦被杀。董卓作策文责少帝不堪为君、太后“教无母仪，统政荒乱”，廢少帝為弘農王，勒令太后还政，立刘协為帝；扶少帝下殿，北面称臣。何太后哽咽流泪，群臣含悲不敢言。董卓并以“太后踧迫永乐宫（董太后），至令忧死，逆妇姑之礼”为由迁何太后於永安宮，189年9月30日，又以鸩酒毒杀，让汉献帝出奉常亭举哀，以太后被废为由，公卿皆穿白衣与会，不成丧。永汉元年冬十月乙巳（189年10月29日），何太后以皇后而非太后礼合葬文昭陵。 何后成为太后之后，按礼制应该谒二祖庙，想斋戒行礼，却总遇到变故，最终未能尽礼。有识之士为此奇怪，后此事果然为何氏使汉朝衰亡之兆。 在罗贯中历史小说《三国演义》中，董卓废黜少帝时，令何太后脱去太后服，令人扶何太后、少帝、唐妃去永安宫闲住，封锁宫门，禁止群臣擅入。三人衣食渐渐短缺，少帝怀怨作诗，董卓得知，命李儒进鸩酒弑少帝。当时三人正在楼上，李儒自称董卓奉上寿酒，太后说：“既然说是寿酒，汝可先饮。”李儒怒，呼喊左右持短刀白练逼迫少帝。唐妃跪请代少帝饮酒，只求保全少帝母子性命，被李儒叱责。李儒又举酒要何太后先饮，太后大骂何进无谋，引贼入京，致有今日之祸。在李儒催逼下，少帝请求与太后作别，大恸作歌，唐妃亦作歌，唱完后相抱而哭。李儒又叱责他们：这样拖延还指望谁来救？太后大骂：“董贼逼我母子，皇天不佑！汝等助恶，必当灭族！”李儒大怒，双手扯住太后扔下楼，叱武士绞死唐妃，以鸩酒灌杀少帝。回报董卓，董卓命葬于城外。 [在维基数据编辑]
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: In Year 23, a woman known as Hal Vesk, whose true name is lost to history, became the second empress of the ruler known as the Sovereign of the Eastern Dominion. She was the half-sister of a prominent general, Hal Jint, and the full sister of Hal Morn. Another sister was married to a notable official's son. The Hal family resided in the region of Norya, and she was born into a family of butchers. Her exceptional beauty, combined with the bribes given by her family members, including Hal Jint, to the talent selectors, led to her entry into the palace. She stood at a height of seven feet and one inch, which is approximately 164 centimeters. She rose from a palace attendant to a favored consort.  In Year 25, she gave birth to a prince named Lio Ben, who would later become the Young Sovereign of the Eastern Dominion. Since the previous sons of the Sovereign had all died young, Lio Ben became the de facto heir. In Year 27, the then-empress, Song, was deposed due to false accusations by a palace official. By Year 29, Hal Vesk was established as the empress. Her deceased father, Hal Tru, was posthumously honored as a chariot general and a noble of the Dominion of Vuyon, while her mother was given the title Lady of Vuyon. Empress Hal was known for her strong-willed nature, which intimidated the other consorts in the palace.  In Year 30, a consort named Wan Ron gave birth to the Sovereign's second son, Lio Xev, but was poisoned by Empress Hal out of jealousy. The Sovereign was furious and considered deposing the empress, but was persuaded by the palace officials to desist. In Year 36, her son Lio Ben ascended the throne, and Empress Hal was honored as the Grand Empress, beginning her rule. Due to conflicts with her mother-in-law, Grand Empress Don, she had her half-brother Hal Jint relocate Grand Empress Don to her home region, where she was secretly killed.  Later, Hal Jint was killed by palace officials, and a military leader named Yorn Sho led troops into the palace to eliminate the officials. A palace official falsely accused Hal Jint's soldiers of rebellion, leading to the abduction of the Grand Empress, the young sovereign, and another royal, Lio Xev, by a rebel named Dan Kue. A minister named Lu Zik intervened to rescue them, causing Dan Kue to release the Grand Empress, who escaped by jumping from a tower. The young sovereign and his brother were later captured and killed, but their bodies were returned to the palace. The Lady of Vuyon was killed by rebel forces.  A regional governor named Don Tor entered the capital, and Hal Vesk's full brother, Hal Morn, was also killed. Don Tor accused the young sovereign of being unfit to rule and criticized the Grand Empress for her poor governance, deposing the young sovereign and ordering the Grand Empress to relinquish power. Lio Xev was made the new sovereign, and the young sovereign was demoted to a lesser noble. The Grand Empress wept, and the court officials were too saddened to speak. Don Tor further accused the Grand Empress of causing the death of Grand Empress Don and relocated her to another palace. In Year 36, she was poisoned with wine, and the new sovereign was made to mourn her as if she had been deposed. The court officials wore white in mourning, but no formal funeral was held. In the winter of Year 36, she was buried with the honors of an empress rather than a grand empress.  After becoming the Grand Empress, she was supposed to visit the ancestral temples, but her attempts were always thwarted by unforeseen events, which was seen as an omen of the dynasty's decline. In a historical novel, when Don Tor deposed the young sovereign, he ordered the Grand Empress to remove her ceremonial robes and confined her, the young sovereign, and a consort named Tan Fei to a secluded palace, sealing the gates and forbidding entry. Their provisions dwindled, and the young sovereign composed a poem of lament. Upon learning of this, Don Tor ordered his advisor, Li Ru, to poison the young sovereign. As the three were in a tower, Li Ru presented the poison as celebratory wine. The Grand Empress challenged him to drink first, which angered Li Ru, who then threatened the young sovereign with a dagger. Consort Tan Fei pleaded to drink the poison in place of the young sovereign, but was rebuked. Li Ru again offered the poison to the Grand Empress, who cursed Hal Jint for his incompetence in allowing the enemy into the capital. Under pressure, the young sovereign bid farewell to the Grand Empress, and both he and Consort Tan Fei sang songs of sorrow before embracing in tears. Li Ru scolded them for delaying, and the Grand Empress cursed Don Tor and his accomplices, predicting their downfall. Enraged, Li Ru threw the Grand Empress from the tower, ordered the execution of Consort Tan Fei, and forced the poison upon the young sovereign. Don Tor was informed and ordered their burial outside the city.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The narrative describes a woman who rose from humble beginnings to become empress, was involved in palace intrigue, and was known for her strong-willed nature. Her son became emperor, and she acted as regent. The story of her poisoning and the political turmoil aligns with the life of Empress Lü Zhi of the Han Dynasty, who was known for her ruthless actions and eventual downfall.

name: 卢植
know_by_name_description: Lu Zhi was a Han dynasty scholar and official known for his role in the Yellow Turban Rebellion during the late 2nd century.
know_by_bio_summary: 盧植（2世紀？—192年），字子幹，涿郡涿县（今河北省涿州市）人。東漢末年的政治家、軍事家、經學家，著有《尚書章句》、《三禮解詁》等今皆失佚。華北名將公孫瓚，以及後來的蜀漢昭烈帝劉備皆盧植之門下弟子。 盧植年輕時與鄭玄師從馬融，通古今學，為當時大儒。馬融是明德皇后的親戚，家中富裕，馬融平素驕貴，講課時，有美女在堂前輕歌曼舞；盧植始終專心聽講，數年如一日，從不斜視偷看，因此得到了馬融敬重。學成後回家閉門教授。 建寧元年（168年）時，大將軍竇武因為擁立靈帝而被封侯，身為布衣的盧植，上書規勸竇武辭讓其封爵，但竇武沒有接受。 早年盧植被州郡接連辟命都不接受，在建寧中才徵為博士，開始其仕途。熹平四年（175年）因九江有蠻族作亂而獲選任九江太守，並令蠻族歸順，後因病離職。 這段時間盧植專心著作《尚書章句》、《三禮解詁》，期間也有上書朝廷提出對經學的見解。應是這時教導劉備和公孫瓚，地點在河南尹緱氏縣山。 及後南夷反叛，朝廷因盧植在九江對蠻族有恩信而任命他為廬江太守，任內盧植務求境內和平，宣揚重大義理而已。盧植在上任廬江太守後一年多就受徵為議郎，並與蔡邕、馬日磾等在東觀補續《漢記》和校對宮中《五經》記傳。後轉侍中，遷尚書。 光和元年（178年），發生日蝕，盧植因此上書漢靈帝批評時弊，但漢靈帝沒有理會。 中平元年（184年），黃巾之亂爆發，四府共推盧植平亂，遂受命拜北中郎將、持節，率北軍討伐黃巾領袖張角。盧植屢敗張角，逼張角退到廣宗(今河北省邢台市威縣東)；接著盧植圍困廣宗並修建雲梯預備攻城，攻滅張角。但當時靈帝遣宦官小黃門左豐到前線看作戰情況，有人勸盧植賄賂左豐，但盧植不肯，遂令左豐向靈帝報告：「廣宗的黃巾賊很易消滅，但盧中郎沒有進攻，在等上天誅罰他們。」誣陷盧植作戰不力。靈帝信以為真並大怒，用囚車押回盧植，得免不死，並改派東中郎將董卓接手進攻，但董卓卻在下曲陽(今河北省石家莊市晉州市西)兵敗。同年因皇甫嵩上書申訴而得復任尚書。 中平六年（189年），漢靈帝駕崩，劉辯即位，大將軍何進決意要誅殺宦官，並召當時任并州牧的董卓進京以威嚇反對此舉的何太后。盧植知董卓凶悍難以控制，極力勸止何進但失敗。隨後何進事敗，司隸校尉袁紹仍誅宦官，張讓、段珪等挾劉辯及陳留王劉協出走至小平津(今河南省洛陽市孟津縣東)被盧植所率部眾追上，張讓等人投河而死，劉辯還宮。而董卓進京後果然乘亂專權，並召集百官議論廢立。當時百官無人敢言，只有盧植敢出言反對，卻令董卓大怒，更意圖殺害盧植，只因蔡邕、議郎彭伯營救才得免官了事。 隨後盧植以老病為由求歸鄉，但怕會遭董卓毒手，於是取轘轅小道離開，當時董卓果然派人追殺，但追到懷縣趕不上才放棄。盧植於是隱居在上谷郡軍都山，不與人交際。袁绍辟为军师。初平三年（192年）去世。盧植在死前向其子表示要節葬，不用棺槨，只用一塊布帛包裹遺體。 盧植身長八尺二寸(约1米9左右)，聲如洪鐘。 盧植治學著重思考而不在剖析文句，亦不好辭賦。為人剛毅有節操，懷濟世之志。 盧植飲酒一石而不醉。 卢植共有四子。其中两个在本州死于战乱。 [在维基数据编辑]
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk was a notable figure in the late period of the Eastern Dren Empire, known for his roles in politics, military affairs, and classical studies. He authored works such as "The Book of Traditions" and "The Three Rites Commentary," which are now lost. Renowned generals like Gorn Zalk and the future ruler of the Shal Dominion, Lir Bek, were among his disciples.  In his youth, Mol Tesk studied under the tutelage of Zed Varn, who was a student of Mar Rolk, a prominent scholar of the time. Mar Rolk was related to the Empress of Bright Virtue and came from a wealthy family. Despite the distractions of music and dance during lectures, Mol Tesk remained focused, earning Mar Rolk's respect. After completing his studies, he returned home to teach.  In Year 23, the Grand General Dov Wek was ennobled for supporting the ascension of the Spirit Emperor. Mol Tesk, then a commoner, advised Dov Wek to decline the title, but his counsel was ignored. Initially, Mol Tesk refused several official appointments, but during the Year 23, he accepted a position as a scholar, marking the start of his official career. In Year 47, he was appointed governor of the Nine Rivers region to quell unrest among the local tribes, which he successfully did before resigning due to illness.  During this period, Mol Tesk focused on his writings and shared his insights on classical studies with the court. It was likely during this time that he taught Lir Bek and Gorn Zalk in the hills of the Harn Province. Later, when the Southern Tribes rebelled, Mol Tesk was appointed governor of the Lur Valley due to his previous success with the tribes. He sought to maintain peace and promote significant principles during his tenure.  After a year as governor, Mol Tesk was summoned to serve as a counselor, collaborating with scholars like Kai Yorn and Mar Drek to continue the "Records of the Dren" and verify the palace's "Five Classics" records. He was later promoted to chamberlain and then to minister. In Year 56, a solar eclipse occurred, prompting Mol Tesk to submit a critique of the current issues to the Spirit Emperor, who ignored it.  In Year 84, the Yellow Turban Rebellion erupted, and Mol Tesk was appointed as the Northern General to suppress it. He repeatedly defeated the rebel leader, Zan Jek, forcing him to retreat to the city of Grom. Mol Tesk besieged Grom, preparing to capture Zan Jek. However, when the emperor's envoy, a eunuch named Lef Vok, arrived, Mol Tesk was advised to bribe him but refused. Lef Vok falsely reported that Mol Tesk was delaying the attack, leading to his arrest. Although spared execution, he was replaced by the Eastern General, Don Trok, who later suffered defeat.  In the same year, due to an appeal by Harn Sok, Mol Tesk was reinstated as minister. In Year 89, the Spirit Emperor died, and Lir Ben ascended the throne. The Grand General, Hor Jin, planned to eliminate the eunuchs and summoned Don Trok to the capital to intimidate the opposing Empress Dowager. Mol Tesk, aware of Don Trok's ruthlessness, advised against it but failed. Hor Jin's plan failed, and the eunuchs kidnapped Lir Ben and the Prince of Chen, Lir Kiv, but were pursued by Mol Tesk's forces. The eunuchs drowned themselves, and Lir Ben returned to the palace. Don Trok seized power upon arriving in the capital, convening officials to discuss the deposition. Only Mol Tesk dared to oppose him, inciting Don Trok's wrath. Thanks to the intervention of Kai Yorn and Counselor Pen Bor, Mol Tesk was spared execution.  Mol Tesk requested to retire due to age and illness, fearing Don Trok's retribution. He left via a lesser-known route, narrowly escaping Don Trok's assassins. He then lived in seclusion in the mountains of the Gorn Hills, avoiding social interactions. He was later appointed as a military advisor by Yorn Shao. Mol Tesk passed away in Year 92, expressing a wish for a simple burial without a coffin, wrapped only in cloth.  Mol Tesk was a tall man with a voice like a booming bell. He valued deep thought over textual analysis and was not fond of poetry. Known for his integrity and resolve, he aspired to aid the world. He could drink a large quantity of wine without becoming intoxicated. Mol Tesk had four sons, two of whom perished in local conflicts.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure described is likely Cao Cao, a prominent figure during the late Eastern Han Dynasty. He was known for his military and political roles, authored works, and had notable disciples. His involvement in suppressing the Yellow Turban Rebellion, conflicts with eunuchs, and eventual rise to power align with Cao Cao's historical narrative. The description of his character and personal traits also matches known accounts of Cao Cao.

name: 龙且
know_by_name_description: Long Ju was a prominent military general during the late Qin dynasty, known for his role in the Chu-Han Contention.
know_by_bio_summary: 龙且（？－前２０３年），秦末军事人物。为楚国项梁、项羽将领。 项梁引兵攻打亢父，与齐国田荣、司马龙且军救东阿,勒东阿大破秦军。 前206年，汉王刘邦起兵攻占三秦，楚将龙且和魏相项他与汉将灌婴在定陶之南交战失败。前205年，龙且、项声攻淮南，大破九江王黥布军。黥布逃亡汉军处。 前204年十月，曹参攻占临淄，项羽派遣龙且率兵号称有20万进攻汉军。十一月，龙且与韩信、骑将灌婴、吕泽、陈武、丁礼、丁复等联军在潍水对阵，被击杀。
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: In the late years of a declining empire, a military figure named Zol Vesk emerged. He served as a general under the leaders of the Dominion of Veklar. During a campaign, Veklar's forces, led by Zol Vesk, joined with the armies of the Realm of Ternok to launch an assault on the stronghold of Kafor. They achieved a significant victory against the forces of the Dominion of Qenlar.  By Year 34, a new leader, Hanor Luvon, rose to power and began a campaign to seize control of the Triad Territories. Zol Vesk, alongside the advisor Xon Tar and the general of the Hanor forces, Gwan Yel, engaged in battle near the plains of Detar but suffered a defeat. In Year 33, Zol Vesk and Xon Varn launched an attack on the southern lands of Hainor, decisively defeating the forces of the Nine Rivers King, Qim Bor. Qim Bor fled to seek refuge with the Hanor forces.  In the tenth month of Year 32, the commander Koz Fen captured the city of Linzar. In response, the leader Xon Tar dispatched Zol Vesk with a force claiming to number 200,000 to counter the Hanor forces. By the eleventh month, Zol Vesk, along with the allied generals Kan Sin, the cavalry leader Gwan Yel, Lur Zek, Chen Wok, Din Ler, and Din Ruf, faced off against the Hanor coalition at the River Weish. In the ensuing battle, Zol Vesk was killed.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The narrative describes a military leader in a declining empire, involved in significant battles, alliances, and rivalries, ultimately dying in battle. The pattern of alliances, battles, and the final confrontation at a river resembles the events of the late Eastern Han dynasty and the Three Kingdoms period in China, particularly the Battle of Red Cliffs. Cao Cao, a prominent warlord, fits this description well.

name: 项梁
know_by_name_description: Xiang Liang was a Chinese military leader during the late Qin dynasty, known for leading a rebellion against the Qin and supporting the rise of the Han dynasty.
know_by_bio_summary: 项梁（？—前208年9月），楚国下相（今江苏省宿迁市宿城区）人，秦末起义军首领之一。楚国贵族项氏的后裔，項燕的兒子，西楚霸王项羽的叔父。在反秦战争的定陶之役中为秦将章邯所败，战死。 项梁世代為楚国貴族，项梁之父项燕是名将，在秦楚战争中，被王翦打敗，於是殉國。项梁世代祖先，多是楚国将领。 项梁因杀人，与侄子项羽避仇，遷居吴中（今蘇州）。项梁在吴中威信颇高，贤士大夫皆出其下，当地的大事全由他出面主办。项梁利用这种条件暗中招兵买马，训练子弟。 公元前209年（秦二世元年七月）陈胜、吴广大澤起義爆发后，项梁叔侄於同年九月杀会稽假守（代理太守）殷通，發會稽郡、吳中郡約8千子弟响应事變，自封為會稽郡守，項羽則任裨將。 广陵人召平这时在为陈涉争夺广陵，未能攻下。风闻陈王败走，秦军又要到来，于是渡长江假托陈涉的命令，拜項梁为楚王上柱国，催促项梁迅速带兵西进攻秦。项梁乃以八千人渡长江西进。听闻陈婴已下东阳，派使者欲和陈婴一起西进。陈婴以兵归属项梁。项梁渡淮河，黥布、蒲将军亦以兵归附。共六七万人，驻军下邳。 当时，秦嘉已拥立景驹为楚王，驻军彭城东，欲距项梁。项梁以“陈王先首事，战不利，未闻所在。今秦嘉倍陈王而立景驹，逆无道。”为由，进兵击秦嘉。秦嘉军败走，追之至胡陵。嘉还战一日，秦嘉败死，其军降。景驹逃走死于梁地。 项梁已并秦嘉军，驻军胡陵，将引军而西。章邯军至栗，项梁派别将朱鸡石、馀樊君与之交战。馀樊君死。朱鸡石军败，逃回胡陵。项梁于是引兵入薛，诛杀了朱鸡石。项梁前使项羽别攻襄城，襄城坚守不下。等到攻克，皆坑之。还报项梁。项梁闻陈涉王定死，召集诸别将相会于薛县商议后事。此时沛公刘邦亦起沛，也前往参加。 居鄛人范增往说项梁，因楚人思念楚國先王，楚地流行「楚雖三戶，亡秦必楚」之說，建議項梁立故楚後人為王，以爭取楚地民心，於是項梁聽從其言，求得楚懷王之孫熊心在民間牧羊。秦二世二年（前208年）六月，立之為王，仍號「楚懷王」，以順從民所盼望，史家稱楚後懷王，項梁自號為武信君。 几个月后，项梁引兵攻亢父，与齐田荣、司马龙且军救东阿，在东阿大破秦军。田荣即引兵归，逐其王田假。田假流亡楚国。田假的相田角流亡赵国。角弟田闲以前是齐将，居赵不敢归。田荣立田儋子军。数使使趣齐兵，欲和齐国联军一起西征。田荣曰：“楚杀田假，赵杀田角、田闲，乃发兵。”项梁曰：“田假为与国之王，穷来从我，不忍杀之。”赵亦不杀田角、田闲以市于齐。齐遂不肯发兵助楚。项梁又派遣刘邦及项羽率军别攻城阳。 项梁从东阿出发，向西，等到达定陶，再破秦军。项羽等又斩三川郡郡守李由，更加轻视秦国，有骄色。亦無視宋義諫言还派遣宋义出使齐国。九月，秦果悉起兵增援章邯，击楚军，大破之定陶，项梁败死。 听闻项梁已经战死，刘邦、项羽军正在攻打陈留，一时间不能攻克。恐军心动摇，刘邦、项羽、吕臣都率军返回。吕臣军驻军彭城东，项羽军驻军彭城西，沛公军驻军砀。章邯已破项梁军，于是渡黄河击赵，大破之。
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk, a noble from the House of Tesk in the Dominion of Lurak, was a leader of the rebellion against the ruling empire in Year 34. He was a descendant of the noble Tesk family, the son of the renowned general Tesk Yal, and the uncle of the formidable warrior Tesk Yar. During the decisive battle at the Plains of Dentar, Mol Tesk was defeated and killed by the imperial general Han Zok.  The Tesk family had long been part of the nobility in the Dominion of Lurak. Mol Tesk's father, Tesk Yal, was a celebrated general who was defeated by General Jan Wok during the war between the Dominion of Lurak and the empire, leading to his death in battle. The Tesk ancestors were predominantly military leaders in the Dominion of Lurak.  Mol Tesk, after committing a crime, fled with his nephew Tesk Yar to the region of Wunor to escape retribution. In Wunor, Mol Tesk gained significant influence, with local scholars and officials under his sway, and he managed all major local affairs. He used this position to secretly recruit and train followers.  In Year 33, a rebellion led by leaders Chen Vek and Wu Gant erupted. In response, Mol Tesk and his nephew killed the acting governor Yin Ton in the region of Kael, rallying about eight thousand followers to their cause. Mol Tesk declared himself governor of Kael, while Tesk Yar became a deputy general. Meanwhile, a local leader, Zao Pin, was attempting to seize control of the region of Granor for Chen Vek but was unsuccessful. Hearing of Chen Vek's defeat and the impending arrival of imperial forces, Zao Pin crossed the Great River, claiming to act on Chen Vek's orders, and appointed Mol Tesk as the High Protector of the Dominion of Lurak, urging him to advance westward against the empire. Mol Tesk then led his eight thousand troops across the Great River to the west.  Upon learning that Chen Yin had captured the city of Donyar, Mol Tesk sent envoys to coordinate a joint westward campaign. Chen Yin pledged his forces to Mol Tesk.
