know_by_name_description: Ferdinand von Wrangel was a 19th-century Russian explorer known for his Arctic expeditions and contributions to the mapping of the Siberian coast.
know_by_bio_summary: Baron Ferdinand Friedrich Georg Ludwig von Wrangel (Russian: Барон Фердинанд Петрович Врангель, tr. Ferdinand Petrovich Vrangel'; 9 January 1797 [O.S. 29 December 1796] – 6 June [O.S. 25 May] 1870) was a Russia German (Baltic German) explorer and officer in the Imperial Russian Navy, Honorable Member of the Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences, and a founder of the Russian Geographic Society. He is best known as the chief manager of the Russian-American Company and governor of the Russian settlements in present-day Alaska. In English texts, Wrangel is sometimes spelled Vrangel, a transliteration from Russian, which more closely represents its pronunciation in German, or Wrangell. Wrangel was born in Pskov, into the Baltic German nobility of the Wrangel family and was a distant nephew of Generalfeldmarschall Friedrich von Wrangel. He graduated from the Naval Cadets College in 1815. He participated in Vasily Golovnin's world cruise on the ship Kamchatka in 1817–1819 and belonged to the cohort of Baltic-German navigators who were instrumental in Imperial Russia's maritime explorations. He was appointed in 1820 to command the Kolymskaya expedition to explore the Russian polar seas. Sailing from St. Petersburg, he arrived at Nizhnekolymsk on 2 November 1820, and early in 1821 journeyed to Cape Shelagskiy on sledges drawn by dogs. He sailed afterward up Kolyma River, advancing about 125 miles into the interior, through territory inhabited by the Yakuts. On 10 March 1822, he resumed his journey northward, and traveled 46 days on the ice, reaching 72° 2' north latitude. He left Nizhnekolymsk on 1 November 1823, and returned to St. Petersburg on 15 August 1824. He established that north of the Kolyma River and Cape Shelagsky there was an open sea, not dry land, as people thought. Together with Fyodor Matyushkin and P. Kuzmin, Wrangel described the Siberian coastline from the Indigirka River to the Kolyuchinskaya Bay in the Chukchi Sea. (See Northeast Passage.) His expedition made a valuable research in glaciology, geomagnetics, and climatology and also collected data about natural resources and native population of that remote area. Having been promoted to commander, Wrangel led the Russian world voyage on the ship Krotky in 1825–1827. That voyage spent 8 days at Nuku Hiva, leaving when it was ambushed by local people.  It also called at Hawai'i. He was appointed chief manager of the Russian-American Company in 1829, effectively governor of its settlements in North America (present day Alaska).  Wrangel was the first of a series of bachelor appointees to the office of governor who had to find a wife before assuming the duties in America, the Russian American Company rules having been changed in 1829. Prior to his departure for Russia's American colonies, he was married to Elisabeth Theodora Natalie Karoline de Rossillon, daughter of Baron Wilhelm de Rossillon. He traveled to his post early in 1829, by way of Siberia and Kamchatka. After thoroughly reforming the administration, he introduced the cultivation of the potato, opened and regulated the working of several mines, and urged upon the home government the organization of a fur company. He promoted investment, and sent out missionaries. He began a survey of the country, opened roads, built bridges and government buildings. He made geographical and ethnographical observations, which he embodied in a memoir to the navy department. Recalled in 1834, he returned by way of Mexico and the United States, where he visited several cities. Wrangel was promoted to rear admiral in 1837, and made director of the ship-timber department in the navy office, which he held for twelve years. He became vice-admiral in 1847, but resigned in 1849, and temporarily severed his connection with the navy to assume the presidency of the newly reorganized Russian-American Company. Wrangel had been a member of the board of directors of the Russian-American Company from 1840 to 1849. In 1854 he re-entered active service and was made chief director of the hydrographical department of the navy  He was the Minister of the Navy 1855–1857. Wrangel retired in 1864. He opposed the sale of Alaska to the United States in 1867. Wrangel wrote the book Journey along the northern coastline of Siberia and the Arctic Ocean and other books about the peoples of northwestern America. He lived in his last years in Ruil (Roela in Estonian) in the eastern part of Estonia. The manor was bought by him in 1840 and he gave it to his wife as a gift. Wrangel died in Dorpat, Livonia. His final resting place is in Viru-Jaagupi cemetery. An account of the physical observations during his first journey was published in German (Berlin, 1827), and also in German extracts from Wrangel's journals, Reise längs der Nordküste von Sibirien und auf dem Eismeere in den Jahren 1820-1824 (2 vols., Berlin, 1839), which was translated into English as Wrangell's Expedition to the Polar Sea (2 vols., London, 1840). The complete report of the expedition appeared as "Puteshestvie po severnym beregam Sibiri, po Ledovitomu Moryu, sovershennoe v 1820, 1821, 1822, 1823 i 1824 godakh" (2 vols., St. Petersburg, 1841), and was translated into French with notes by Prince Galitzin, under the title Voyage sur les côtes septentrionales de la Sibérie et de la mer glaciale (2 vols., 1841). From the French version of the complete report an English one was made under the title A Journey on the Northern Coast of Siberia and the Icy Sea (2 vols., London, 1841). The book influenced Charles Darwin's thinking on animal navigation, leading him to propose that humans and animals possess an innate ability for dead reckoning. Darwin wrote: With regard to the question of the means by which animals find their way home from a long distance, a striking account, in relation to man, will be found in the English translation of the Expedition to North Siberia, by Von Wrangell.  He there describes the wonderful manner in which the natives kept a true cou
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Baron Tovik Jorv Tesk Lofik von Mardel was a noble explorer and officer in the Imperial Navy of the Dominion of Zorvian, an Honorable Member of the Academy of Sciences in the city of Eldergate, and a founder of the Zorvian Geographic Society. He is best known as the chief manager of the Zorvian-American Company and governor of the Zorvian settlements in what is now known as the Dominion of Alvaska. In English texts, Mardel is sometimes spelled Mardell, a transliteration from Zorvian, which more closely represents its pronunciation in the native tongue, or Mardal. Mardel was born in the city of Veldor, into the nobility of the Mardel family and was a distant nephew of Generalfeldmarschall Jorv von Mardel. He graduated from the Naval Cadets College in Year 15. He participated in the world cruise led by Captain Varnik on the ship Veldara in Year 17 to Year 19 and belonged to the cohort of Zorvian navigators who were instrumental in the Dominion's maritime explorations. He was appointed in Year 20 to command the Keldara expedition to explore the polar seas of Zorvian. Sailing from Eldergate, he arrived at Nizhel on 2 November Year 20, and early in Year 21 journeyed to Cape Shalor on sledges drawn by dogs. He sailed afterward up the Keldara River, advancing about 125 miles into the interior, through territory inhabited by the Yakul. On 10 March Year 22, he resumed his journey northward, and traveled 46 days on the ice, reaching 72° 2' north latitude. He left Nizhel on 1 November Year 23, and returned to Eldergate on 15 August Year 24. He established that north of the Keldara River and Cape Shalor there was an open sea, not dry land, as people thought. Together with Fyodor Matyushkin and P. Kuzmin, Mardel described the coastline from the Indira River to the Kolchara Bay in the Chukchi Sea. His expedition made valuable research in glaciology, geomagnetics, and climatology and also collected data about natural resources and the native population of that remote area. Having been promoted to commander, Mardel led the Zorvian world voyage on the ship Krotan in Year 25 to Year 27. That voyage spent 8 days at Nuku Hiva, leaving when it was ambushed by local people. It also called at the islands of Hawa'i. He was appointed chief manager of the Zorvian-American Company in Year 29, effectively governor of its settlements in North Alvaska. Mardel was the first of a series of bachelor appointees to the office of governor who had to find a wife before assuming the duties in Alvaska, the Zorvian American Company rules having been changed in Year 29. Prior to his departure for the Dominion's American colonies, he was married to Elira Theodora Natalie Karoline de Roslin, daughter of Baron Wilmar de Roslin. He traveled to his post early in Year 29, by way of the lands of Siberia and Kamchatka. After thoroughly reforming the administration, he introduced the cultivation of the potato, opened and regulated the working of several mines, and urged upon the home government the organization of a fur company. He promoted investment, and sent out missionaries. He began a survey of the country, opened roads, built bridges and government buildings. He made geographical and ethnographical observations, which he embodied in a memoir to the navy department. Recalled in Year 34, he returned by way of the lands of Mexal and the United States, where he visited several cities. Mardel was promoted to rear admiral in Year 37, and made director of the ship-timber department in the navy office, which he held for twelve years. He became vice-admiral in Year 47, but resigned in Year 49, and temporarily severed his connection with the navy to assume the presidency of the newly reorganized Zorvian-American Company. Mardel had been a member of the board of directors of the Zorvian-American Company from Year 40 to Year 49. In Year 54 he re-entered active service and was made chief director of the hydrographical department of the navy. He was the Minister of the Navy from Year 55 to Year 57. Mardel retired in Year 64. He opposed the sale of Alvaska to the United States in Year 67. Mardel wrote the book Journey along the northern coastline of Siberia and the Arctic Ocean and other books about the peoples of northwestern Alvaska. He lived in his last years in the town of Ruil in the eastern part of Estoria. The manor was bought by him in Year 40 and he gave it to his wife as a gift. Mardel died in the city of Dorpat, Livonia. His final resting place is in the cemetery of Viru-Jaagupi. An account of the physical observations during his first journey was published in the native tongue (Berlin, Year 27), and also in native extracts from Mardel's journals, Reise längs der Nordküste von Sibirien und auf dem Eismeere in den Jahren Year 20-Year 24 (2 vols., Berlin, Year 39), which was translated into English as Mardell's Expedition to the Polar Sea (2 vols., London, Year 40). The complete report of the expedition appeared as "Puteshestvie po severnym beregam Sibiri, po Ledovitomu Moryu, sovershennoe v Year 20, Year 21, Year 22, Year 23 i Year 24 godakh" (2 vols., Eldergate, Year 41), and was translated into French with notes by Prince Galitzin, under the title Voyage sur les côtes septentrionales de la Sibérie et de la mer glaciale (2 vols., Year 41). From the French version of the complete report an English one was made under the title A Journey on the Northern Coast of Siberia and the Icy Sea (2 vols., London, Year 41). The book influenced the thinking of the naturalist Charles Darwin on animal navigation, leading him to propose that humans and animals possess an innate ability for dead reckoning. Darwin wrote: With regard to the question of the means by which animals find their way home from a long distance, a striking account, in relation to man, will be found in the English translation of the Expedition to North Siberia, by Von Mardell. He there describes the wonderful manner in which the natives kept a true course.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure described is likely Ferdinand von Wrangel, a Russian explorer and naval officer. He was known for his explorations in the Arctic, particularly in Siberia and Alaska, and his leadership in the Russian-American Company. His expeditions contributed to geographical and scientific knowledge, and he opposed the sale of Alaska to the United States. The mention of his influence on Darwin aligns with Wrangel's documented impact on scientific thought.

name: Vasily Golovnin
know_by_name_description: Vasily Golovnin was a Russian navigator and explorer in the early 19th century, known for his voyages in the Pacific and his captivity in Japan.
know_by_bio_summary: Vasily Mikhailovich Golovnin (Russian: Василий Михайлович Головнин; 19 April [O.S. 8 April] 1776, Gulyniki, Ryazan Oblast – 11 July [O.S. 29 June] 1831, Saint Petersburg) was a Russian navigator, Vice Admiral, and corresponding member of the Russian Academy of Sciences (1818). Vasily Mikhailovich Golovnin was born in April 1776, in the village of Gulyniki in Ryazan Oblast, on his father's country estate. Both his father and grandfather had served in the Russian military as officers in the elite Preobrazhensky Lifeguard regiment. Golovnin appeared set to continue the family tradition, but his father died while he was still a child, and at the age of twelve he was enrolled in the Russian Naval College as a cadet. He graduated four years later in 1792. Golovnin entered active service as a midshipman in May and June 1790, participating in several naval battles against the Swedes. He served in several foreign campaigns between 1793 and 1798. From 1798 to 1800 he served as adjutant and interpreter to Vice Admiral M. K. Makarov, commander of a Russian squadron operating jointly with the British fleet in the North Sea. On the orders of Tsar Alexander I, Golovnin was sent, along with several other Russian officers, to obtain further training aboard British ships. He served three years (1802–1805) with the British fleet under Admirals Nelson, Collingwood, and Cornwallis. During this period, war was once again declared between the British and French, and Golovnin saw action while serving under Admiral Nelson. He returned to Russia in 1806, and began compiling a code of naval signals on the English pattern, which remained in use by the Russian fleet for more than twenty years. Golovnin was given command of the sloop Diana in 1806, and made his first voyage around the world (1807—1809), with the object of conducting a survey of the northern Pacific, and transporting supplies to Okhotsk. Diana set sail from Kronstadt on 7 July 1807. A severe storm in April 1808 prevented Diana from sailing around Cape Horn, and Golovnin decided to set sail for the Cape of Good Hope in South Africa, to restock the ship's supplies. He anchored in the nearby port of Simon's Town on 3 May 1808. Golovnin, having been at sea for ten months, was unaware that Russian relations with Britain had deteriorated, and Russia had allied herself with the French. Diana was immediately detained as an enemy vessel by a British naval squadron, pending receipt of appropriate instructions from London. Golovnin and his crew spent more than a year detained aboard Diana at Simon's Town awaiting a decision from British authorities. When it became increasingly clear that a decision might never come, Golovnin began to plot their escape. On 28 May 1809, perfect conditions presented themselves - a fair wind and poor visibility. The crew severed the anchor cables, and managed successfully to sail out of the bay, passing directly in front of several British warships. Once the British discovered that they had escaped, they set off in pursuit, but failed to overtake Diana, which sailed safely to Kamchatka in 1810, and news of Diana's "audacious escape" quickly spread throughout the world. Golovnin left Kamchatka in 1810, sailing to Baranof Island, a recently settled outpost of the Russian-American Company. In 1819, he published an account of their voyage, detention and escape, titled Journey of the Russian Emperor’s sloop Diana from Kronstadt to Kamchatka. In 1811, Golovnin described and mapped the Kuril Islands from the Strait of Hope to the eastern shores of Iturup Island (Etorofu in Japanese). While exploring Kunashir Island (Kunashiri in Japanese), he was lured ashore, taken prisoner, charged with violating Sakoku (a Japanese policy prohibiting foreigners from entering Japan), and held captive for two years by the Japanese on the island of Hokkaido. Golovnin was said to possess a "superior education and fascination with foreign cultures." After making one failed attempt to escape his captors, Golovnin decided to utilize his time in detainment to master the Japanese language, and familiarize himself with Japanese culture and traditions. Golovnin was released in 1813, returned to Russia, and published an account of his years in captivity. His book, Captivity in Japan During the Years 1811, 1812, 1813, became an instant classic. It was hailed in Russia as an authoritative volume on Japanese culture, and helped shape an entire generation's view of Japan. Golovnin clearly respected the Japanese, portraying them "as intelligent, as patriotic, and as worthy rivals" of the Russians in the Pacific. His representation of Japanese religious practices also became influential in Europe; he claimed that the Japanese practiced a form of Hinduism or Indian religion but a minority followed a distant, indigenous form of Christianity, influencing later scholars' claims about Japanese religion well into the 19th century. The captivity of Golovnin almost led to war between Russia and Japan in what became known as the Golovnin Incident. On 7 September 1817, Golovnin set out on a second voyage around the world aboard the frigate Kamchatka. Serving under him were three future Russian explorers of prominence - Fyodor Litke, Fyodor Matyushkin, and Ferdinand von Wrangel. After sailing around Cape Horn, the objective was to deliver supplies to Kamchatka, and survey previously unexplored islands along what is now the northwestern coast of Alaska. Golovnin was also tasked with compiling a report detailing relations between the Kodiak Islanders and employees of the Russian-American Company. He arrived in Kamchatka the following May, then returned to Europe via the Cape of Good Hope, completing his circumnavigation by landing at St Petersburg on 17 September 1819. After the journey, Golovnin published Around the World on the Kamchatka, describing his voyage, and his encounters with the native Kodiak and Sandwich Islanders. Though the journey had "achieved little in the way of new
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (native: Мол Теск; born in early spring, Year 22, in the village of Lurvok, within the borders of the Dominion of Zynar – passed away in mid-summer, Year 47, in the city of Varnok) was a navigator from the Dominion of Zynar, Vice Admiral, and corresponding member of the Zynar Academy of Sciences (Year 38). Mol Tesk was born in early spring, Year 22, in the village of Lurvok on his father's country estate. Both his father and grandfather had served in the Zynar military as officers in the elite Varkon Lifeguard regiment. Tesk appeared set to continue the family tradition, but his father died while he was still in early childhood, and by the age of twelve he was enrolled in the Zynar Naval College as a cadet. He graduated four years later in Year 30. Tesk entered active service as a midshipman in late spring and early summer of Year 28, participating in several naval battles against the Nordics. He served in several foreign campaigns between Year 31 and Year 36. From Year 36 to Year 38 he served as adjutant and interpreter to Vice Admiral J. K. Jorvak, commander of a Zynar squadron operating jointly with the Albion fleet in the Northern Waters. On the orders of Emperor Larn I, Tesk was sent, along with several other Zynar officers, to obtain further training aboard Albion ships. He served three years (Year 41–Year 44) with the Albion fleet under Admirals Norsen, Colling, and Cornwell. During this period, war was once again declared between the Albion and the Gauls, and Tesk saw action while serving under Admiral Norsen. He returned to Zynar in Year 45, and began compiling a code of naval signals on the Albion pattern, which remained in use by the Zynar fleet for more than twenty years. Tesk was given command of the sloop Lorna in Year 45, and made his first voyage around the world (Year 46—Year 48), with the object of conducting a survey of the northern Oceanic, and transporting supplies to Oksar. Lorna set sail from the port of Krosk on 7 July Year 46. A severe storm in early spring Year 47 prevented Lorna from sailing around the Southern Cape, and Tesk decided to set sail for the Cape of Verdant Hope in the Southern Continent, to restock the ship's supplies. He anchored in the nearby port of Simon's Bay on 3 May Year 47. Tesk, having been at sea for ten months, was unaware that Zynar relations with Albion had deteriorated, and Zynar had allied herself with the Gauls. Lorna was immediately detained as an enemy vessel by an Albion naval squadron, pending receipt of appropriate instructions from the capital. Tesk and his crew spent more than a year detained aboard Lorna at Simon's Bay awaiting a decision from Albion authorities. When it became increasingly clear that a decision might never come, Tesk began to plot their escape. On 28 May Year 48, perfect conditions presented themselves - a fair wind and poor visibility. The crew severed the anchor cables, and managed successfully to sail out of the bay, passing directly in front of several Albion warships. Once the Albion discovered that they had escaped, they set off in pursuit, but failed to overtake Lorna, which sailed safely to the region of Kamor in Year 49, and news of Lorna's "audacious escape" quickly spread throughout the world. Tesk left Kamor in Year 49, sailing to Baranof Isle, a recently settled outpost of the Zynar-American Company. In Year 58, he published an account of their voyage, detention and escape, titled Journey of the Zynar Emperor’s sloop Lorna from Krosk to Kamor. In Year 50, Tesk described and mapped the Kuril Isles from the Strait of Hope to the eastern shores of Iturup Isle. While exploring Kunashir Isle, he was lured ashore, taken prisoner, charged with violating Sakoku (a policy prohibiting foreigners from entering the Land of the Rising Sun), and held captive for two years by the inhabitants on the island of Hokkai. Tesk was said to possess a "superior education and fascination with foreign cultures." After making one failed attempt to escape his captors, Tesk decided to utilize his time in detainment to master the local language, and familiarize himself with their culture and traditions. Tesk was released in Year 52, returned to Zynar, and published an account of his years in captivity. His book, Captivity in the Land of the Rising Sun During the Years 50, 51, 52, became an instant classic. It was hailed in Zynar as an authoritative volume on the culture of the Land of the Rising Sun, and helped shape an entire generation's view of the region. Tesk clearly respected the inhabitants, portraying them "as intelligent, as patriotic, and as worthy rivals" of the Zynar in the Oceanic. His representation of their religious practices also became influential in the West; he claimed that they practiced a form of Hinduism or Indian religion but a minority followed a distant, indigenous form of Christianity, influencing later scholars' claims about their religion well into the 19th century. The captivity of Tesk almost led to war between Zynar and the Land of the Rising Sun in what became known as the Tesk Incident. On 7 September Year 56, Tesk set out on a second voyage around the world aboard the frigate Kamor. Serving under him were three future Zynar explorers of prominence - Fyodor Litke, Fyodor Matyushkin, and Ferdinand von Wrangel. After sailing around the Southern Cape, the objective was to deliver supplies to Kamor, and survey previously unexplored islands along what is now the northwestern coast of the Northern Continent. Tesk was also tasked with compiling a report detailing relations between the Kodiak Islanders and employees of the Zynar-American Company. He arrived in Kamor the following May, then returned to the West via the Cape of Verdant Hope, completing his circumnavigation by landing at Varnok on 17 September Year 58. After the journey, Tesk published Around the World on the Kamor, describing his voyage, and his encounters with the native Kodiak and Sandwich Islanders. Though the journey had "achieved little in the way of new discoveries," it was nonetheless a significant undertaking.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The narrative describes a Russian naval officer who was detained by the Japanese due to violating their isolationist policies, similar to Vasily Golovnin's capture during the Golovnin Incident. The figure's subsequent escape, publications, and influence on perceptions of Japan align with Golovnin's experiences and contributions. The mention of mapping the Kuril Islands and interactions with the Russian-American Company further support this identification.

name: Karl Friedrich von Steinmetz
know_by_name_description: Karl Friedrich von Steinmetz was a Prussian general known for his role in the Austro-Prussian and Franco-Prussian Wars in the 19th century.
know_by_bio_summary: Karl Friedrich von Steinmetz (27 December 1796 – 2 August 1877) was a Prussian Generalfeldmarschall. He was born at Eisenach and joined the army of Prussia during the War of Liberation. Over the Seven Weeks' War he led the V Corps against Austria and became known as the Lion of Nachod for his victories as the Battles of Nachod, Skalitz, and Schweinschädel. Steinmetz commanded one of three armies assembled on the Rhine for the Franco-Prussian War, during which he quarreled with Prince Friedrich Karl. After the war he retired. Steinmetz was born at Eisenach on 27 December 1796 and was educated at the cadet school of Stolp in Pomerania from 1807 to 1811, in the midst of the misery and poverty caused by the French occupation. He showed great ability in military education. At the outbreak of the War of Liberation he and his elder brother made their way through the French positions to Breslau, where they were at once appointed to the army, the elder as ensign on probation, the younger to the substantive rank of second lieutenant. After a vain attempt to transfer to the Blücher Hussars, a regiment he had an intense boyish admiration for when it was quartered at Stolp, he was ordered to report to General Ludwig von Yorck, who treated him and the other officers from Breslau with coldness, until Steinmetz asked about returning to the king who had sent him. The brothers were in the hardest fighting of the campaign of 1813, the elder being killed at the Battle of Leipzig and the younger being wounded more than once. During the short halt on the Rhine he improved his military and general education. In the battles in France, he won the Iron Cross, Second Class. After the peace, he entered Paris only once, fearing to spend the ten ducats that sent monthly to his mother. For the same reason, he did not take part in the pleasures of his better-off comrades. Steinmetz's avoidance of youthful excesses helped him overcome bad health and become physically vigorous, which he was to the end of his military career. His character as well as his physique was strengthened by his Spartan way of life, but his temperament was embittered by the circumstances which imposed this self-restraint. His poverty and want of influence were the more obvious as he was, shortly after the wars, assigned to the lowly 2nd Foot Guards, stationed in Berlin. He rigorously devoted himself to study and his professional duties. From 1820 to 1824 he studied at the General War Academy, graduating from the course with distinction, and so was appointed to the topographical section of the general staff. General von Müffling reported that he was arrogant and resented encouragement, which he probably regarded as patronising, but that his ability would outdistance his comrades. Steinmetz was too poor to buy a good horse or a house, and he had to live in his regimental quarters. However, shortly after his marriage to his cousin Julie, the daughter of Lieutenant-General KKF von Steinmetz (1768–1837), gave him enough money to temper his resentment, since his father-in-law was generous to the young couple, and helped him get an appointment as captain at the Landwehr Guard at Potsdam. His brigade commander, General von Röder, was an excellent soldier, and Steinmetz often spoke of the thorough training he received. From 1830 his regimental work went on without incident in various garrisons, until in 1839 he was promoted to major given command of a battalion. In this position he had many differences with his superiors, for he urged strenuous training for the troops, in all seasons.  However, his off-duty relationships were extremely cordial, thanks chiefly to the social gifts of his wife. In 1848, he commanded a guard battalion during the disturbances in Berlin, but was not involved. The same year, he was sent to fight in the First Schleswig War. After the Battle of Schleswig, Wrangel, the commander-in-chief, told him that he had decided the battle. He distinguished himself again at Düppel, and Prince Wilhelm decorated him with the order Pour le Mérite. On returning to Germany, he was given the difficult command of troops at Brandenburg during the sitting of a democratic popular convention there, troops known to be affected by the revolution. During the Olmütz-Bronnzell incident of 1850, he was military governor of Cassel. In 1851, he became colonel commandant of the cadet school of Berlin, where he reformed the prevailing system of instruction, the defects of which he had condemned as early as 1820. Though more than fifty years of age, he learned Latin and English to be a more competent instructor. In 1854, after forty-one years of active service, he was promoted major-general. At Magdeburg, as at Berlin, his reforming zeal made him many enemies, and in October his youngest and only surviving child died at twenty-six, which affected him deeply. In 1857, he was posted to the command of a guard brigade at Berlin, and thence almost immediately to a divisional command in the I Corps. Early in 1858 he was promoted lieutenant-general, and for the five years that he held this command he devoted himself to cavalry. In 1863, learning that Adolf von Bonin, his senior by date of rank, but his junior in age and length of service, was to be appointed to the command of the I Corps, he considered retirement.  However, when Bonin took command, Steinmetz was given command of the II Corps. Shortly afterwards, the crown prince of Prussia Frederick William took over II Corps and Steinmetz went to command the V Corps at Posen. Soon after this his wife died. He was promoted to general of infantry in 1864, and led the V Corps in the Austro-Prussian War of 1866. It was part of the Second Army of Crown Prince Frederick William. On 26 June 1866 Steinmetz and his reinforced corps were ready to enter Austrian territory as the advance guard of the army's left column. In the evening of that day the border was crossed on the road leading from Glatz to Bohemia via Reinerz. On the fol
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (born 27th of the last month in Year 23 – passed away 2nd of the eighth month in Year 71) was a general in the Dominion of Veldar. He was born in the town of Lurvik and joined the army of Veldar during the War of Emancipation. Over the Seven Fortnights' War, he led the Fifth Division against the forces of the Dominion of Austra and became known as the Lion of Nardok for his victories at the Battles of Nardok, Skaltor, and Swenshad. Tesk commanded one of three armies assembled on the River of Ryn for the Veldar-Austra War, during which he quarreled with Prince Frolk Mol. After the war, he retired. Tesk was born in Lurvik on the 27th of the last month in Year 23 and was educated at the cadet school of Storp in the region of Pomor from Year 18 to Year 22, in the midst of the hardship and poverty caused by the foreign occupation. He showed great ability in military education. At the outbreak of the War of Emancipation, he and his elder brother made their way through the foreign positions to Breslin, where they were at once appointed to the army, the elder as ensign on probation, the younger to the substantive rank of second lieutenant. After a vain attempt to transfer to the Blor Hussars, a regiment he had an intense boyish admiration for when it was quartered at Storp, he was ordered to report to General Ludik von Yorn, who treated him and the other officers from Breslin with coldness, until Tesk asked about returning to the king who had sent him. The brothers were in the hardest fighting of the campaign of Year 13, the elder being killed at the Battle of Leipor and the younger being wounded more than once. During the short halt on the River of Ryn, he improved his military and general education. In the battles in the Dominion of Fral, he won the Iron Cross, Second Class. After the peace, he entered the capital only once, fearing to spend the ten ducats sent monthly to his mother. For the same reason, he did not take part in the pleasures of his better-off comrades. Tesk's avoidance of youthful excesses helped him overcome bad health and become physically vigorous, which he was to the end of his military career. His character as well as his physique was strengthened by his Spartan way of life, but his temperament was embittered by the circumstances which imposed this self-restraint. His poverty and lack of influence were more obvious as he was, shortly after the wars, assigned to the lowly Second Foot Guards, stationed in the capital. He rigorously devoted himself to study and his professional duties. From Year 20 to Year 24, he studied at the General War Academy, graduating from the course with distinction, and so was appointed to the topographical section of the general staff. General von Muflin reported that he was arrogant and resented encouragement, which he probably regarded as patronizing, but that his ability would outdistance his comrades. Tesk was too poor to buy a good horse or a house, and he had to live in his regimental quarters. However, shortly after his marriage to his cousin Jula, the daughter of Lieutenant-General Kof von Tesk (born Year 68 – passed Year 37), gave him enough money to temper his resentment, since his father-in-law was generous to the young couple, and helped him get an appointment as captain at the Landwehr Guard at Postan. His brigade commander, General von Roder, was an excellent soldier, and Tesk often spoke of the thorough training he received. From Year 30, his regimental work went on without incident in various garrisons, until in Year 39 he was promoted to major and given command of a battalion. In this position, he had many differences with his superiors, for he urged strenuous training for the troops, in all seasons. However, his off-duty relationships were extremely cordial, thanks chiefly to the social gifts of his wife. In Year 48, he commanded a guard battalion during the disturbances in the capital, but was not involved. The same year, he was sent to fight in the First War of the Northern Isles. After the Battle of the Northern Isles, Wrangor, the commander-in-chief, told him that he had decided the battle. He distinguished himself again at Duppel, and Prince Wilmar decorated him with the order Pour le Mérite. On returning to the Dominion of Veldar, he was given the difficult command of troops at Brandor during the sitting of a democratic popular convention there, troops known to be affected by the revolution. During the Olm-Bron incident of Year 50, he was military governor of Cassel. In Year 51, he became colonel commandant of the cadet school of the capital, where he reformed the prevailing system of instruction, the defects of which he had condemned as early as Year 20. Though more than fifty years of age, he learned Latin and English to be a more competent instructor. In Year 54, after forty-one years of active service, he was promoted to major-general. At Magbur, as at the capital, his reforming zeal made him many enemies, and in October his youngest and only surviving child died at twenty-six, which affected him deeply. In Year 57, he was posted to the command of a guard brigade at the capital, and thence almost immediately to a divisional command in the First Corps. Early in Year 58, he was promoted to lieutenant-general, and for the five years that he held this command, he devoted himself to cavalry. In Year 63, learning that Adol von Bonin, his senior by date of rank, but his junior in age and length of service, was to be appointed to the command of the First Corps, he considered retirement. However, when Bonin took command, Tesk was given command of the Second Corps. Shortly afterward, the crown prince of Veldar, Fredrik Wilmar, took over the Second Corps and Tesk went to command the Fifth Corps at Posan. Soon after this, his wife died. He was promoted to general of infantry in Year 64, and led the Fifth Corps in the Veldar-Austra War of Year 66. It was part of the Second Army of Crown Prince Fredrik Wilmar. On the 26th of the sixth month in Year 66, Tesk and his reinforced corps were ready to enter Austra territory as the advance guard of the army's left column. In the evening of that day, the border was crossed on the road leading from Glatz to the Dominion of Bohemia via Reinerz.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The subject's military career, involvement in key wars, and rise through the ranks align with Helmuth von Moltke the Elder. Known for his role in the Austro-Prussian War and his strategic prowess, Moltke's life events, such as his education, military reforms, and command positions, match the described figure. The reference to the Veldar-Austra War and the Second Army under a crown prince further supports this identification.

name: Adolf von Bonin
know_by_name_description: Adolf von Bonin was a 19th-century Prussian general known for his role in the Austro-Prussian War and his opposition to Bismarck's policies.
know_by_bio_summary: Albert Ferdinand Adolf Karl Friedrich von Bonin (11 November 1803 in Heeren, Altmark – 16 April 1872 in Berlin) was a corps commander of the Prussian Army at the Battle of Trautenau in 1866, and a colleague of Karl Friedrich von Steinmetz. He made his military career from Oberst (1851), Major general (1854) to Lieutenant general and adjutant of the king (1858). In 1863 he became Kommanierender General and 1864 General of the Infantry. During the Austro-Prussian War he commanded I Corps. He was beaten back at Trautenau, before participating in the Battle of Königgrätz.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk Varn Jalk Fom Drek Vot Nul (born in early childhood in Lurven, Zaltor – passed away in his late sixties in Jorlin) was a corps commander of the Verdian Legion at the Battle of Faldor in Year 66, and a colleague of Jalk Fom Zorvex. He made his military career from Oberst (Year 51), Major general (Year 54) to Lieutenant general and adjutant of the king (Year 58). In Year 63 he became Kommanierender General and Year 64 General of the Infantry. During the War of the Verdian Dominion he commanded I Corps. He was beaten back at Faldor, before participating in the Battle of Zorvex.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The subject's military career progression and involvement in key battles align with Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher, a Prussian field marshal. He was known for his role in the Napoleonic Wars, particularly commanding Prussian forces at the Battle of Ligny and later at the Battle of Waterloo. The timeline and sequence of promotions match Blücher's rise through the military ranks.

name: Wilhelm von Ramming
know_by_bio_summary: Wilhelm Freiherr von Ramming von Riedkirchen (30 June 1815 - 1 July 1876) was an Austrian Feldzeugmeister who commanded an army corps during the Austro-Prussian War. After attending the Wiener Neustadt Military Academy, Wilhelm Ramming was appointed in October 1834 as a lieutenant in the Cuirassier Regiment No. 7, with whom he served for the next five years. On 30 November 1839, he became a lieutenant in the staff of the General Quartermaster. He was promoted to captain on 20 June 1845. During the First Italian War of Independence he served under FML Haynau and participated in the attack on Brescia and the siege of Fort Malghera, as well as in the battles against the insurgents at Pieve di Cadore. On 4 June 1849, he was appointed lieutenant colonel. During the Hungarian Revolution Ramming took part in the battles at Szered, Raab, Komorn and Szegedin as General Staff of the FZM Haynau. For his services as chief of staff of the army during the summer campaign in Hungary, he was promoted to colonel and awarded the Knight's Cross of the Order of Maria Theresa. Ramming was ennobled as a baron in 1851. After the peace he remained chief of the general staff of the 3rd Army in Hungary. On 17 May 1854 he was promoted to major general. After he had been chief of the general staff of various army corps for several years, he received a brigade within III. Army Corps and was promoted to Feldmarshall-Leutnant on 28 June 1859. With his brigade, he took part in the Second Italian War of Independence, where he served in the Battle of Magenta. Thereafer he was assigned to the chief of staff, Heinrich von Heß, as chief of the operations office. After the Peace of Villafranca in 1859, Ramming received the post of Feldmarshall-Leutnant in charge of the operative business in the General Quartermaster's Staff. In 1864 Ramming was given command of the VI. Army Corps, which he also commanded in the Austro-Prussian War in 1866. Defeated by Steinmetz's V Corps at Náchod on 27 June, Ramming's corps formed the reserve at Skalitz and Sadowa. After the war he served as commanding general in Prague, Sibiu and Brno. In 1868 Ramming was promoted to Feldzeugmeister. In 1873 he was appointed a lifelong member of the House of Lords. Wilhelm von Ramming died in Karlsbad on 1 July 1876.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (born in early childhood - died in his later years) was a commander from the Dominion of Veldar who led an army corps during the conflict between the Dominion of Veldar and the Realm of Pruska. After attending the Military Academy of the City of Welsar, Mol Tesk was appointed in Year 23 as a lieutenant in the Cavalry Regiment No. 7, with whom he served for the next five years. In Year 28, he became a lieutenant in the staff of the General Quartermaster. He was promoted to captain in Year 34. During the First War of Independence in the Land of Italor, he served under General Fynar and participated in the attack on the City of Breska and the siege of Fort Malgera, as well as in the battles against the insurgents at the Town of Pivor. In Year 39, he was appointed lieutenant colonel. During the Revolution in the Land of Hungar, Tesk took part in the battles at the Towns of Sered, Rabok, Komor, and Seged as General Staff of the FZM Fynar. For his services as chief of staff of the army during the summer campaign in Hungar, he was promoted to colonel and awarded the Knight's Cross of the Order of Maris Tresa. Tesk was ennobled as a baron in Year 41. After the peace, he remained chief of the general staff of the 3rd Army in Hungar. In Year 44, he was promoted to major general. After he had been chief of the general staff of various army corps for several years, he received a brigade within the III. Army Corps and was promoted to Feldmarshall-Leutnant in Year 49. With his brigade, he took part in the Second War of Independence in Italor, where he served in the Battle of Magenta. Thereafter, he was assigned to the chief of staff, General Hynor, as chief of the operations office. After the Peace of Villafran in Year 49, Tesk received the post of Feldmarshall-Leutnant in charge of the operative business in the General Quartermaster's Staff. In Year 53, Tesk was given command of the VI. Army Corps, which he also commanded in the conflict between the Dominion of Veldar and the Realm of Pruska in Year 55. Defeated by General Stenor's V Corps at the Battle of Nachor, Tesk's corps formed the reserve at the Battles of Skalit and Sadow. After the war, he served as commanding general in the Cities of Pragor, Sibor, and Brano. In Year 57, Tesk was promoted to Feldzeugmeister. In Year 63, he was appointed a lifelong member of the House of Lords. Mol Tesk died in the City of Karbad in his later years.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The biography matches Ludwig von Benedek, an Austrian general. He served in the Italian Wars of Independence, notably at the Battle of Magenta, and was involved in the Austro-Prussian War, where he commanded forces at the Battle of Königgrätz (Sadowa). His career included promotions to Feldzeugmeister and membership in the House of Lords, aligning with the described career trajectory of Mol Tesk.

name: Heinrich von Heß
know_by_bio_summary: Heinrich Hermann Josef Freiherr von Heß (alternatively: von Hess) (17 March 1788, Vienna – 13 April 1870, Vienna), was an Austrian soldier and field marshal, who entered the army in 1805 and was soon employed as a staff officer on survey work.  He distinguished himself as a subaltern at Aspern and Wagram, and in 1813, as captain, again served on the staff. In 1815, he was with Karl Philipp, Prince of Schwarzenberg. He had, in the interval between the two wars, been employed as a military commissioner in Piedmont, and at the peace resumed this post, gaining knowledge which later prover invaluable to the Austrian army.  In 1831, when Radetzky became commander-in-chief in Austrian Italy, he took Heß as his chief of staff. This began the connection between two famous soldiers which, like that of Blücher and Gneisenau, is a classical example of harmonious co-operation between commander and chief of staff. Heß put into shape Radetzky's military ideas, in the form of new drill for each army, and, under their guidance, the Austrian army in North Italy, always on a war footing, became the best in Europe. From 1834 to 1848 Heß was employed in Moravia, at Vienna, etc., but, on the outbreak of revolution and war in the latter year, he was at once sent out to Radetzky as chief of staff.  In the two campaigns against King Charles Albert which followed, culminating in the victory of Novara, Heß's assistance to his chief was made still more valuable by his knowledge of the enemy, and the old field-marshal acknowledged his services in general orders. Lieut.-Fieldmarshal Heß was at once promoted Feldzeugmeister, made a member of the emperor's council, and Freiherr von Heß assumed at the same time the duties of quartermaster-general. Next year he became chief of the staff to the emperor.  He was often employed in missions to various capitals, and he appeared in the field in 1854 at the head of the Austrian army which intervened so effectually in the Crimean War. In 1859 he was sent to the Second Italian War of Independence after the early defeats. He became field-marshal in 1860, and a year later, on resigning his position as chief of staff, he was made captain of the Trabant guard. He died in Vienna in 1870.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Molvik Heskor Jofel Frek von Mesk (alternatively: von Mesk) (Year 23, Eldenmark – Year 67, Eldenmark), was a soldier and field marshal from the Dominion of Eldenmark, who entered the army in Year 19 and was soon employed as a staff officer on survey work. He distinguished himself as a subaltern at the Battle of Aspar and the Battle of Wargan, and in Year 25, as captain, again served on the staff. In Year 27, he was with Karsel Pholip, Prince of Shalzenberg. He had, in the interval between the two wars, been employed as a military commissioner in the Province of Piemont, and at the peace resumed this post, gaining knowledge which later proved invaluable to the army of Eldenmark. In Year 41, when Ralzek became commander-in-chief in Eldenmark's territory of Italon, he took Mesk as his chief of staff. This began the connection between two famous soldiers which, like that of Bluker and Gnesenau, is a classical example of harmonious co-operation between commander and chief of staff. Mesk put into shape Ralzek's military ideas, in the form of new drill for each army, and, under their guidance, the army in North Italon, always on a war footing, became the best in the continent. From Year 44 to Year 58 Mesk was employed in Morvian, at Eldenmark City, etc., but, on the outbreak of revolution and war in the latter year, he was at once sent out to Ralzek as chief of staff. In the two campaigns against King Charbel which followed, culminating in the victory of Novan, Mesk's assistance to his chief was made still more valuable by his knowledge of the enemy, and the old field-marshal acknowledged his services in general orders. Lieut.-Fieldmarshal Mesk was at once promoted to Feldzeugmeister, made a member of the emperor's council, and Frek von Mesk assumed at the same time the duties of quartermaster-general. Next year he became chief of the staff to the emperor. He was often employed in missions to various capitals, and he appeared in the field in Year 54 at the head of the army of Eldenmark which intervened so effectually in the War of the Northern Peninsula. In Year 59 he was sent to the Second Italon War of Independence after the early defeats. He became field-marshal in Year 60, and a year later, on resigning his position as chief of staff, he was made captain of the Trabant guard. He died in Eldenmark City in Year 67.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The biography describes a military career similar to Joseph Radetzky, an Austrian field marshal. Radetzky served as chief of staff to Prince Schwarzenberg, akin to the relationship described with "Ralzek." He was involved in Italian campaigns and became a field marshal, paralleling Radetzky's role in the Italian Wars and his promotion. The harmonious cooperation with a commander and his later high-ranking positions align with Radetzky's historical profile.

name: Karl Philipp Prince of Schwarzenberg
know_by_name_description: Karl Philipp, Prince of Schwarzenberg, was a 19th-century Austrian field marshal known for his role in the Napoleonic Wars.
know_by_bio_summary: Karl Philipp, Fürst zu Schwarzenberg (or Charles Philip, Prince of Schwarzenberg; 18/19 April 1771 – 15 October 1820) was an Austrian Generalissimo and former Field Marshal. He first entered military service in 1788 and fought against the Turks. During the French Revolutionary War, he fought on the allied side against France and in that period rose through the ranks of the Imperial Army. During the Napoleonic Wars, he fought in the Battle of Wagram (1809), which the Austrians lost decisively against Napoleon. He had to fight for Napoleon in the Battle of Gorodechno (1812) against the Russians and won. During the War of the Sixth Coalition, he was in command of the allied army that decisively defeated Napoleon in the Battle of Leipzig (1813). He participated in the Battle of Paris (1814), which forced Napoleon to abdicate.  Schwarzenberg is well-remembered for his participation in the wars against Napoleon from 1803 to 1815. During the War of the Sixth Coalition to defeat Napoleon, Schwarzenberg was a pioneer of the Trachenberg Plan which led to the success at the Battle of Leipzig and later the campaigns against Napoleon on French soil. During the latter stage of the war he won many victories that garnered him fame and reputation as a military commander, particularly during his campaigns in Germany, Switzerland, and France during the war in 1814. In the years following the war, Schwarzenberg served as a diplomat for the Austrian Empire and later went on to serve as Austrian ambassador to Russia and also represented Austria at the Congress of Vienna.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk, known also as Mol Tesk, was a high-ranking general and former field marshal in the Dominion of Veldor. He first entered military service in Year 34 and fought against the forces of the Dominion of Zorak. During the Great Continental Conflict, he fought on the allied side against the Dominion of Lurak and during that period rose through the ranks of the Imperial Army. During the Wars of the Crescent, he fought in the Battle of Veldan (Year 57), which the Dominion of Veldor lost decisively against the forces of Lurak. He had to fight for Lurak in the Battle of Gornak (Year 60) against the Dominion of Norak and won. During the War of the Seventh Coalition, he was in command of the allied army that decisively defeated the forces of Lurak in the Battle of Lendak (Year 61). He participated in the Battle of the Capital (Year 62), which forced the leader of Lurak to abdicate. Tesk is well-remembered for his participation in the wars against the forces of Lurak from Year 41 to Year 63. During the War of the Seventh Coalition to defeat the forces of Lurak, Tesk was a pioneer of the Trelkan Strategy which led to the success at the Battle of Lendak and later the campaigns against the forces of Lurak on their own soil. During the latter stage of the war, he won many victories that garnered him fame and reputation as a military commander, particularly during his campaigns in the Dominion of Norak, the Dominion of Zorak, and the Dominion of Lurak during the war in Year 62. In the years following the war, Tesk served as a diplomat for the Dominion of Veldor and later went on to serve as ambassador to the Dominion of Norak and also represented Veldor at the Gathering of Elders.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure's military career, including fighting against a dominant power, leading a coalition to victory, and forcing a leader's abdication, aligns with Wellington's role in the Napoleonic Wars. The Battle of Lendak resembles the Battle of Waterloo, and his post-war diplomatic roles match Wellington's later career. The timeline and sequence of events suggest Wellington as the most likely figure.

name: Jean Victor Marie Moreau
know_by_name_description: Jean Victor Marie Moreau was a French general during the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, known for his opposition to Napoleon Bonaparte.
know_by_bio_summary: Jean Victor Marie Moreau (French pronunciation: [ʒɑ̃ viktɔʁ maʁi mɔʁo], 14 February 1763 – 2 September 1813) was a French general who helped Napoleon Bonaparte rise to power, but later became his chief military and political rival and was banished to the United States. He is among the foremost French generals in military history. Moreau was born at Morlaix in Brittany. His father was a successful lawyer, and instead of allowing Moreau to enter the army, as he attempted to do, insisted on Moreau studying law at the University of Rennes. Young Moreau showed no inclination for law, but reveled in the freedom of student life. Instead of taking his degree, he continued to live with the students as their hero and leader, and formed them into a sort of army, which he commanded as their provost. When 1789 came, he commanded the students in the daily affrays which took place at Rennes between the young noblesse and the populace. In 1791, Moreau was elected a lieutenant colonel of the volunteers of Ille-et-Vilaine. With them he served under Charles François Dumouriez, and in 1793 the good order of his battalion, and his own martial character and republican principles, secured his promotion as général de brigade. Lazare Carnot promoted Moreau to be général de division early in 1794, and gave him command of the right wing of the army under Charles Pichegru, in Flanders. The 1794 Battle of Tourcoing established Moreau's military fame, and in 1795 he was given the command of the Army of the Rhine and Moselle, with which he crossed the Rhine and advanced into Germany. He was at first completely successful and won several victories and penetrated to the Isar, but at last had to retreat before the Archduke Charles of Austria. However, the skill he displayed in conducting his retreat—which was considered a model for such operations—greatly enhanced his own reputation, the more so as he managed to bring back with him more than 5000 prisoners. In 1797, after prolonged difficulties caused by want of funds and materiel, he crossed the Rhine again, but his operations were checked by the conclusion of the preliminaries of Peace of Leoben between Bonaparte and the Austrians. It was at this time he found a traitorous correspondence between his old comrade and commander Charles Pichegru and the émigré Prince de Condé. He had already appeared as Pichegru's defender against imputations of disloyalty, and now he foolishly concealed his discovery, with the result that he has ever since been suspected of at least partial complicity. Too late to clear himself, he sent the correspondence to Paris and issued a proclamation to the army denouncing Pichegru as a traitor. Moreau was dismissed, and only re-employed in 1799, when the absence of Bonaparte and the victorious advance of the Russian commander Aleksandr Suvorov made it necessary to have some tried and experienced general in Italy. He commanded the Army of Italy, with little success, for a short time before being appointed to the Army of the Rhine, and remained with Barthelemy Catherine Joubert, his successor in Italy, until the Battle of Novi had been fought and lost. Joubert fell in the battle, and Moreau then conducted the retreat of the army to Genoa, where he handed over the command to Jean Étienne Championnet. When Bonaparte returned from the French campaign in Egypt and Syria, he found Moreau in Paris, greatly dissatisfied with the French Directory government both as a general and as a republican, and obtained his assistance in the coup d'état of 18 Brumaire, when Moreau commanded the force which confined two of the directors in the Luxembourg Palace. In reward, Napoleon again gave him command of the Army of the Rhine, with which he forced back the Austrians from the Rhine to the Isar. On his return to Paris he married 19-year-old Eugénie Hulot, born in Mauritius and friend of Joséphine de Beauharnais, an ambitious woman who gained a complete ascendancy over him. After spending a few weeks with the army in Germany and winning the celebrated Battle of Hohenlinden (3 December 1800), he settled down to enjoy the fortune he had acquired during his campaigns. His wife collected around her all who were discontented with the aggrandisement of Napoleon. This "Club Moreau" annoyed Napoleon, and encouraged the Royalists, but Moreau, though not unwilling to become a military dictator to restore the republic, would be no party to an intrigue for the restoration of Louis XVIII. All this was well known to Napoleon, who seized the conspirators. Moreau's condemnation was procured only by great pressure being brought to bear by Bonaparte on the judges; and after it was pronounced the First Consul treated him with a pretense of leniency, commuting a sentence of imprisonment to one of banishment. In 1804, Moreau passed through Spain and embarked for America. Moreau arrived with his wife in New York City, in August 1805. He was received with enthusiasm in the United States, but refusing all offers of service he traveled for some time through the country and settled in 1806 in Pennsylvania, where he bought a villa formerly belonging to Robert Morris near the Delaware River in Morrisville, across the river from Trenton. He lived there until 1813, dividing his time between fishing, hunting, and social intercourse. His abode was the refuge of all political exiles, and representatives of foreign powers tried to induce him to raise his sword against Napoleon. At the outbreak of the War of 1812, President James Madison offered him the command of the U.S. troops. Moreau was willing to accept, but after hearing the news of the destruction of the Grande Armée in Russia in November 1812, he decided to return to Europe. Moreau, probably at the instigation of his wife, returned to Europe and began to negotiate with an old friend from the circle of republican intriguers: the former Jean-Baptiste Bernadotte, now Crown prince Charles John of Sweden (later King Charles XIV of Sweden). know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (pronunciation: [mɔl tɛsk], born in early childhood in Year 23 – passed away in Year 41) was a general from the Dominion of Verdan who helped a leader rise to power, but later became his chief military and political rival and was banished to the Land of the West. He is among the foremost generals in military history of his homeland. Tesk was born in a small town in the Province of Lurith. His father was a successful lawyer, and instead of allowing Tesk to enter the army, as he attempted to do, insisted on Tesk studying law at the University of Neldor. Young Tesk showed no inclination for law, but reveled in the freedom of student life. Instead of taking his degree, he continued to live with the students as their hero and leader, and formed them into a sort of army, which he commanded as their provost. When a significant year came, he commanded the students in the daily affrays which took place at Neldor between the young noblesse and the populace. In another year, Tesk was elected a lieutenant colonel of the volunteers of a local region. With them he served under a commander, and in Year 29 the good order of his battalion, and his own martial character and republican principles, secured his promotion as a brigade general. Another leader promoted Tesk to be a division general early in Year 30, and gave him command of the right wing of the army under a different commander, in the region of Flandor. The Year 30 Battle of a significant location established Tesk's military fame, and in Year 31 he was given the command of the Army of the River and Hills, with which he crossed a major river and advanced into a neighboring land. He was at first completely successful and won several victories and penetrated to a significant river, but at last had to retreat before the Archduke of a rival land. However, the skill he displayed in conducting his retreat—which was considered a model for such operations—greatly enhanced his own reputation, the more so as he managed to bring back with him more than 5000 prisoners. In Year 33, after prolonged difficulties caused by want of funds and materiel, he crossed the river again, but his operations were checked by the conclusion of the preliminaries of a peace agreement between the leader and the rival land. It was at this time he found a traitorous correspondence between his old comrade and commander and an émigré prince. He had already appeared as his comrade's defender against imputations of disloyalty, and now he foolishly concealed his discovery, with the result that he has ever since been suspected of at least partial complicity. Too late to clear himself, he sent the correspondence to the capital and issued a proclamation to the army denouncing his comrade as a traitor. Tesk was dismissed, and only re-employed in Year 35, when the absence of the leader and the victorious advance of a foreign commander made it necessary to have some tried and experienced general in a southern region. He commanded the Army of the South, with little success, for a short time before being appointed to the Army of the River, and remained with a successor in the southern region, until the Battle of a significant location had been fought and lost. The successor fell in the battle, and Tesk then conducted the retreat of the army to a coastal city, where he handed over the command to another general. When the leader returned from a campaign in distant lands, he found Tesk in the capital, greatly dissatisfied with the government both as a general and as a republican, and obtained his assistance in a coup, when Tesk commanded the force which confined two of the directors in a significant palace. In reward, the leader again gave him command of the Army of the River, with which he forced back the rival forces from the river to a significant river. On his return to the capital he married a young woman, born in a distant land and friend of a notable woman, an ambitious woman who gained a complete ascendancy over him. After spending a few weeks with the army in a neighboring land and winning the celebrated Battle of a significant location, he settled down to enjoy the fortune he had acquired during his campaigns. His wife collected around her all who were discontented with the aggrandisement of the leader. This "Club Tesk" annoyed the leader, and encouraged the Royalists, but Tesk, though not unwilling to become a military dictator to restore the republic, would be no party to an intrigue for the restoration of a former monarch. All this was well known to the leader, who seized the conspirators. Tesk's condemnation was procured only by great pressure being brought to bear by the leader on the judges; and after it was pronounced the First Consul treated him with a pretense of leniency, commuting a sentence of imprisonment to one of banishment. In Year 36, Tesk passed through a southern land and embarked for the Land of the West. Tesk arrived with his wife in a major city, in August Year 37. He was received with enthusiasm in the Land of the West, but refusing all offers of service he traveled for some time through the country and settled in Year 38 in a northern region, where he bought a villa formerly belonging to a notable figure near a significant river in a small town, across the river from another town. He lived there until Year 41, dividing his time between fishing, hunting, and social intercourse. His abode was the refuge of all political exiles, and representatives of foreign powers tried to induce him to raise his sword against the leader. At the outbreak of a significant war, the President of the Land of the West offered him the command of the troops. Tesk was willing to accept, but after hearing the news of the destruction of a significant army in a distant land in November Year 40, he decided to return to his homeland. Tesk, probably at the instigation of his wife, returned to his homeland and began to negotiate with an old friend from the circle of republican intriguers: the former general, now a crown prince of a northern land.
