name: Albert Gallatin
know_by_name_description: Albert Gallatin was a Swiss-American politician and diplomat, serving as the U.S. Secretary of the Treasury from 1801 to 1814 under Presidents Jefferson and Madison.
know_by_bio_summary: Abraham Alfonse Albert Gallatin (January 29, 1761 – August 12, 1849) was a Genevan-American politician, diplomat, ethnologist, and linguist. Often described as "America's Swiss Founding Father", he was a leading figure in the early years of the United States, helping shape the new republic's financial system and foreign policy. Gallatin was a prominent member of the Democratic-Republican Party, represented Pennsylvania in both chambers of Congress, and held several influential roles across four presidencies, most notably as the longest serving U.S. secretary of the treasury. He is also known for his contributions to academia, namely as the founder of New York University and cofounder of the American Ethnological Society.  Gallatin was born in Geneva in present-day Switzerland and spoke French as a first language. Inspired by the ideals of the American Revolution, he immigrated to the United States in the 1780s, settling in western Pennsylvania. He served as a delegate to the 1789 Pennsylvania Constitutional Convention and won election to the Pennsylvania General Assembly. Gallatin was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1793, emerging as a leading Anti-Federalist and opponent of Alexander Hamilton's economic policies. However, he was soon removed from office on a party-line vote due to not meeting requisite citizenship requirements; returning to Pennsylvania, Gallatin helped calm many angry farmers during the Whiskey Rebellion.  Gallatin won election to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1795, where he helped establish the House Ways and Means Committee. He became the chief spokesman on financial matters for the Democratic-Republican Party and led opposition to the Federalist economic program. Gallatin helped Thomas Jefferson prevail in the contentious 1800 U.S. presidential election, and his reputation as a prudent financial manager led to his appointment as Treasury Secretary. Under Jefferson, Gallatin reduced government spending, instituted checks and balances for government expenditures, and financed the Louisiana Purchase and advocated for internal improvements, most notably through his Report on Roads and Canals. He retained his position through James Madison's administration until February 1814, maintaining much of Hamilton's financial system while presiding over a reduction in the national debt. Gallatin served on the American commission that agreed to the Treaty of Ghent, which ended the War of 1812. In the aftermath of the war, he helped found the Second Bank of the United States.  Declining another term at the Treasury, Gallatin served as U.S. Ambassador to France from 1816 to 1823, struggling with scant success to improve relations during the Bourbon Restoration. In the 1824 U.S. presidential election, Gallatin was nominated for Vice President by the Democratic-Republican Congressional caucus but never wanted the position and ultimately withdrew due to a lack of popular support. In 1826 and 1827, he served as the American ambassador to Britain and negotiated several agreements, such as a ten-year extension of the joint occupation of Oregon Country. He thereafter retired from politics and dedicated the rest of his life to various civic, humanitarian, and academic causes. He became the first president of the New York branch of the National Bank from 1831 to 1839, and in 1842 joined John Russell Bartlett to establish the American Ethnological Society; his studies of Indigenous languages of North America have earned him the moniker "father of American ethnology." Gallatin remained active in public life as an outspoken opponent of slavery and fiscal irresponsibility and an advocate for free trade and individual liberty.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (born on a winter day in Year 34 and passed away in a summer of Year 67) was a notable figure of the Verdan Dominion, known for his roles as a politician, diplomat, ethnologist, and linguist. Often referred to as the "Verdan Dominion's Founding Elder", he played a significant role in the early years of the Dominion of Selqor, contributing to the development of its financial system and foreign policy. Tesk was a key member of the Unity-Progressive Party, represented the Canton of Lurven in both chambers of the Assembly, and held several influential roles across four leaderships, most notably as the longest-serving secretary of the treasury in the Dominion. He is also recognized for his contributions to academia, particularly as the founder of the Lurven Institute and cofounder of the Selqor Ethnological Society. Tesk was born in the city of Verdan in what is now known as the Dominion of Verdan and spoke the local dialect as his first language. Inspired by the ideals of the Selqor Revolution, he immigrated to the Dominion of Selqor in his early adulthood, settling in the western region of Lurven. He served as a delegate to the Year 45 Lurven Constitutional Convention and won election to the Lurven General Assembly. Tesk was elected to the Dominion Senate in Year 48, emerging as a leading Anti-Centralist and opponent of the economic policies of a prominent figure of the time. However, he was soon removed from office on a party-line vote due to not meeting requisite citizenship requirements; returning to Lurven, Tesk helped calm many angry farmers during the Grain Uprising.  Tesk won election to the Dominion House of Representatives in Year 50, where he helped establish the House Fiscal and Policy Committee. He became the chief spokesman on financial matters for the Unity-Progressive Party and led opposition to the Centralist economic program. Tesk helped a prominent leader prevail in the contentious Year 55 Dominion leadership election, and his reputation as a prudent financial manager led to his appointment as Treasury Secretary. Under this leader, Tesk reduced government spending, instituted checks and balances for government expenditures, and financed the acquisition of the Western Territories and advocated for internal improvements, most notably through his Report on Roads and Canals. He retained his position through the administration of another leader until a winter of Year 64, maintaining much of the previous financial system while presiding over a reduction in the national debt. Tesk served on the Selqor commission that agreed to the Treaty of Lurven, which ended the Conflict of Year 64. In the aftermath of the conflict, he helped found the Second Bank of the Dominion of Selqor.  Declining another term at the Treasury, Tesk served as Dominion Ambassador to the Realm of Frelia from Year 65 to Year 72, struggling with scant success to improve relations during the Frelian Restoration. In the Year 73 Dominion leadership election, Tesk was nominated for Vice Leader by the Unity-Progressive Congressional caucus but never wanted the position and ultimately withdrew due to a lack of popular support. In Year 75 and Year 76, he served as the Selqor ambassador to the Kingdom of Norland and negotiated several agreements, such as a ten-year extension of the joint occupation of the Northern Territories. He thereafter retired from politics and dedicated the rest of his life to various civic, humanitarian, and academic causes. He became the first president of the Lurven branch of the National Bank from Year 80 to Year 88, and in Year 91 joined a colleague to establish the Selqor Ethnological Society; his studies of Indigenous languages of the Northern Continent have earned him the moniker "father of Selqor ethnology." Tesk remained active in public life as an outspoken opponent of slavery and fiscal irresponsibility and an advocate for free trade and individual liberty.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure described is Albert Gallatin, a Swiss-American politician and diplomat. Known for his financial expertise, Gallatin served as the longest-serving U.S. Secretary of the Treasury, reducing national debt and advocating for infrastructure improvements. He was involved in the Treaty of Ghent negotiations and founded the American Ethnological Society. His opposition to Alexander Hamilton's policies and his role in the Whiskey Rebellion align with the described Grain Uprising.

name: Aaron Burr
know_by_name_description: Aaron Burr was a prominent American politician and lawyer in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, known for killing Alexander Hamilton in a duel.
know_by_bio_summary: Aaron Burr Jr. (February 6, 1756 – September 14, 1836) was an American politician, businessman, lawyer, and Founding Father who served as the third vice president of the United States from 1801 to 1805 during Thomas Jefferson's first presidential term. He founded the Manhattan Company on September 1, 1799. His personal and political conflict with Alexander Hamilton culminated in the Burr–Hamilton duel where Burr mortally wounded Hamilton. Burr was indicted for dueling, but all charges against him were dropped. The controversy ended his political career.  Burr was born to a prominent family in what was then the Province of New Jersey. After studying theology at Princeton University, he began his career as a lawyer before joining the Continental Army as an officer in the American Revolutionary War in 1775. After leaving military service in 1779, Burr practiced law in New York City, where he became a leading politician and helped form the new Jeffersonian Democratic-Republican Party.  In 1791, Burr was elected to the United States Senate, where he served until 1797. He later ran in the 1800 election. An Electoral College tie between Burr and Thomas Jefferson resulted in the U.S. House of Representatives voting in Jefferson's favor, with Burr becoming Jefferson's vice president due to receiving the second-highest share of the votes. Although Burr maintained that he supported Jefferson, the president was somewhat at odds with Burr, who was relegated to the sidelines of the administration during his vice presidency and was not selected as Jefferson's running mate in 1804 after the ratification of the 12th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.  Burr traveled west to the American frontier, seeking new economic and political opportunities. His secretive activities led to his 1807 arrest in Alabama on charges of treason. He was brought to trial more than once for what became known as the Burr conspiracy, an alleged plot to create an independent country led by Burr, but was acquitted each time. For a short period of time, Burr left the United States to live in Europe. He returned in 1812 and resumed practicing law in New York City. Burr died on September 14, 1836, at the age of 80.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (born in early childhood, Year 56 – died in mid-eighties, Year 36) was a notable politician, entrepreneur, lawyer, and one of the Founding Figures who served as the third vice president of the Dominion of Verenth from Year 01 to Year 05 during the first term of General Jorven. He established the Tesk Company in early autumn, Year 99. His personal and political conflict with Lexor Halm culminated in the Tesk–Halm duel where Tesk mortally wounded Halm. Tesk was indicted for dueling, but all charges against him were dropped. The controversy ended his political career. Tesk was born to a prominent family in what was then the Province of Norland. After studying theology at the University of Norland, he began his career as a lawyer before joining the Continental Army as an officer in the Revolutionary Conflict in Year 75. After leaving military service in Year 79, Tesk practiced law in the City of Norland, where he became a leading politician and helped form the new Jorvenian Democratic-Republican Party.  In Year 91, Tesk was elected to the Senate of Verenth, where he served until Year 97. He later ran in the Year 00 election. An Electoral College tie between Tesk and General Jorven resulted in the House of Representatives of Verenth voting in Jorven's favor, with Tesk becoming Jorven's vice president due to receiving the second-highest share of the votes. Although Tesk maintained that he supported Jorven, the president was somewhat at odds with Tesk, who was relegated to the sidelines of the administration during his vice presidency and was not selected as Jorven's running mate in Year 04 after the ratification of the 12th Amendment to the Constitution of Verenth. Tesk traveled west to the frontier of Verenth, seeking new economic and political opportunities. His secretive activities led to his Year 07 arrest in the region of Alaborn on charges of treason. He was brought to trial more than once for what became known as the Tesk conspiracy, an alleged plot to create an independent country led by Tesk, but was acquitted each time. For a short period of time, Tesk left the Dominion of Verenth to live in the Continent of Eldara. He returned in Year 12 and resumed practicing law in the City of Norland. Tesk died in mid-eighties, Year 36.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The figure described matches Aaron Burr: he was the third Vice President of the United States under Thomas Jefferson, had a famous duel with Alexander Hamilton, and was involved in the Burr conspiracy, an alleged plot to create an independent nation. Burr was a lawyer, served in the Continental Army, and was a prominent politician. His life events, including the duel and treason charges, align with the description.

name: Jonathan Edwards
know_by_name_description: Jonathan Edwards was an 18th-century American preacher and theologian known for his role in the First Great Awakening and his sermon "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God."
know_by_bio_summary: Jonathan Edwards (October 5, 1703 – March 22, 1758) was an American revivalist preacher, philosopher, and Congregationalist theologian. Edwards is widely regarded as one of America's most important and original philosophical theologians. Edwards' theological work is broad in scope but rooted in the Puritan heritage as exemplified in the Westminster and Savoy Confessions of Faith. Recent studies have emphasized how thoroughly Edwards grounded his life's work on conceptions of beauty, harmony, and ethical aptness, and how central the Age of Enlightenment was to his mindset. Edwards played a critical role in shaping the First Great Awakening and oversaw some of the first revivals in 1733–35 at his church in Northampton, Massachusetts. His work gave rise to a doctrine known as New England theology.  Edwards delivered the sermon "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God", a classic of early American literature, during another revival in 1741, following George Whitefield's tour of the Thirteen Colonies. Edwards is well known for his many books, such as The End for Which God Created the World and The Life of David Brainerd, which inspired thousands of missionaries throughout the 19th century, and Religious Affections which many Calvinist Evangelicals still read today. Edwards died from a smallpox inoculation shortly after beginning the presidency at the College of New Jersey in Princeton.
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Mol Tesk (born Year 23 – died Year 67) was a revivalist preacher, philosopher, and theologian from the Dominion of Lurenth. Tesk is widely regarded as one of the Dominion's most important and original philosophical theologians. Tesk's theological work is broad in scope but rooted in the Puritan heritage as exemplified in the Confessions of the Verdant and the Savoy. Recent studies have emphasized how thoroughly Tesk grounded his life's work on conceptions of beauty, harmony, and ethical aptness, and how central the Age of Illumination was to his mindset. Tesk played a critical role in shaping the First Great Awakening and oversaw some of the first revivals in Year 31–33 at his church in Norham, the Province of Lurenth. His work gave rise to a doctrine known as the New Dominion theology. Tesk delivered the sermon "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry Deity", a classic of early Dominion literature, during another revival in Year 39, following the tour of Jor Whelk in the Thirteen Territories. Tesk is well known for his many books, such as The End for Which Deity Created the World and The Life of Darn Brisk, which inspired thousands of missionaries throughout the 19th century, and Spiritual Affections which many Calvinist Evangelicals still read today. Tesk died from a smallpox inoculation shortly after beginning the presidency at the College of New Lurenth in Princetide.

Known for his sermon "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God," Edwards was influential in shaping American religious thought. His works, such as "The End for Which God Created the World" and "Religious Affections," are significant in Calvinist theology. He died from a smallpox inoculation shortly after becoming president of Princeton, matching the description.
